The morning the letter came, mist hung low over the canal and clung to the orange peel of streetlamps along the Gürtel. Magda Rieder stood barefoot in the tiled kitchen, one hand on the small enamel coffee pot, the other cradling a piece of stale bread, a gift from the bakery below that never closed on a weekday. Steam curled in the windowpane as if it wanted to write something. Her cat, who was not a cat by law or taxonomy but by convenience, watched the kettle with ears lifted, head cocked, thinking about heat in a way that had nothing to do with flames.

“A day of keys,” Magda said to no one. “A day for locks to notice.”

The coffee bloomed in the pot with a low sound that she always thought was relief. Magda had two clocks in her kitchen: an old brass one that ran five minutes fast and a newer one that was never right for long. Between the two she—more than once—had made appointments happen exactly when she meant them to. Some mornings she turned both to face the wall and waited for the apartment to lose its grip on time. Those were not days for the market or the laundromat or the municipal office with its tickets and numbers gliding up digital red in orderly increments. But this was not one of those mornings. Today the clocks ticked honestly in the manner of things that thought they weren’t being watched.

Outside, a tram groaned, took a corner by flinging its weight around, and clattered away along the rails. A woman on her balcony across the courtyard smoked, her breath a small white ghost. Somewhere a radio squabbled in a language that had too many consonants for before nine a.m., which meant Czech or just German delivered by a man with a mouth full of pastry. Magda opened the window a sliver and slipped a sprig of winter savory onto the sill. Smoke came in, and the courtyard’s cold, damp breath, and from the bakery downstairs the scent of yeast and butter and that burnt sugar bitterness that came from forgetting a tray and then pretending you meant to.

Her phone buzzed with a message from Petra, who had been her friend since they were both apprentices and had mistaken a hymn for a recipe—Magda never tired of that story, though Petra felt differently.

G’mornin, it read. Coffee later? They say she’s on again tonight. Fourth time. Impossible. Except, well, you know how that word likes to slip its shoes off.

Magda looked down at the coffee’s oily surface, where a few bubbles were drifting in toward the center, and let her thumb hover. She could pretend to have slept through the message. That would be a way to be unkind without claiming it. Soft cruelties were a thing she had tried to learn to do without. She wrote: I saw. If it’s the same she. We can watch and be irritated. At eight?

Petra sent back a heart, and a gif of a woman rolling her eyes so theatrically that it should have knocked her off the chair. The cat, whose name changed often enough that it was all cats and no particular one, wound its body around Magda’s ankles and purred and hummed things into the floorboards. The building took it all and gave back a small old warmth.

There were days when Magda considered going out to the canal, sitting by the water tucked into her coat, and convincing herself she was a civilian. One of those women with a novel open in one hand and a half-eaten apple in the other, the world juicy and really hers. But then the old metal letterbox lid in the hall would cluck, and she would remember the particular smell of stamped envelopes and municipal notices and the cheap ink of flyers for yoga and tax attorneys. That cluck was a kind of shiver in the skin. Today it came early. And saw another half second later, the slow slide of something heavy on old metal.

She held her coffee like a talisman and went to the door. The hallway air felt different, as if it had been instructed, a minor adjustment in humidity, a whisper of something violets were famous for. The metal lid drooped. In the shadow of the box’s mouth, a rectangle, cream paper, thick as bread. The envelope waited without patience, which is to say it waited because there was no other option. She pulled it free and turned it over, and the outside of it was unmarked except for a stamp that was nothing like a stamp and a small chalk line someone had dragged across the top flap and then smudged with a finger. In the place where a return address should have been there was instead a black wax seal, and pressed into the wax: a question mark in the shape of a hooked fish. Under the curve of the question mark, a small, old, almost florid letter D.

Three things happened in her body at once: her stomach sank but also rose—like an elevator no one had asked for—her skin cooled with a suddenness like stepping into the shadow of a bus, and the place at the base of her skull where the oldest kind of knowing lived blew open. The cat lifted its head and then laid it back down and sighed. They had known this might happen. That is to say: Magda thought she had prepared for it, and the cat had prepared to not be surprised by whatever happened.

She locked the door behind her on the corridor side, out of long habit, and went back to the kitchen. The kettle saluted her, the water ready to be coerced into tea if not coffee. She set the envelope down on the table where the damp had warped the wood and the wood had taken the message poorly. The black wax had a smell that wasn’t just wax. Something sweet and rank at once, like overripe figs. It clung to the back of her throat. The seal had bled a little onto the paper. She thought of the question mark as a fish and of fish in the Danube and of the Danube swallowing things and spitting them back up on a beach in the wrong country. She thought of a studio’s bright lights and a chair in which a woman had sat last week, ankles crossed neatly, dark hair pinned up with something that had belonged to her grandmother, two of the assistants having bleached their teeth too much.

“Brava,” she said to the envelope. “You got the smell right.”

Are you going to open it, asked the cat in the language that is not spoken and so needs no grammar. The cat's question was a picture of the envelope’s belly and the possibility of knives.

“I don't have to,” Magda said. “You saw the seal. It’s as open as anything is before it is opened.”

The cat made a sound like the smallest iron bell. You will pick the wrong knife if you are too proud about it.

She brewed another small cup of coffee into a chipped demitasse and spooned a thread of dark honey into it, then set this next to the envelope like an offering left on a stoop in a fable. The steam found the black wax and made it blush; Magda watched a drop form and hover before it rolled, slow and syrupy, toward the wood. She drew a circle with her index finger around the cup and the letter, then another, thinking the words that had taught her not to say them out loud. The first circle was for the place; the second was for the old things that cared about place. In the way a humble circle drawn with breath and intent can be.

And then—of course—she opened it. Not with a knife, after all. With her thumb, pressed into the wax’s black and under it a thin layer of something that clung like sleep to eyelashes. The paper tore with the sort of sound that makes ink stand up and pay attention. Inside, a single sheet, thick but not as thick as it pretended to be. The handwriting was done by a person who had made a private study of angles and pressure, and of the way old feuds need a particular slant to how they’re announced.

Honored Magda Rieder, it began. By the right of public oath and by the privilege of contest held in the old municipalities and yet in the new media, I extend you invitation. The letters stood up and dipped in a rhythm that wasn’t European. It pulled from a little bit of everywhere because some people think that makes them universal.

Under that, the details. The among lines and the officiants and the conditions of refusal, which were none in the old ways and worse in the new. The place was named and then named again to remove the possibility of error: at the Prater’s edge, under the big wheel, cabin seven, at the eighth turn after eight bells on the eighth day from this. There is a way to write eight where it looks like a snake chewing its own tail, and she had done that. And then the name of the sender in an even darker ink as if Part of her wanted it to be tattooed on the reader’s eye. Zita Dorn. The stage name screamed with modesty—because modesty is a rival you never really meant to invite. Under it, in parentheses, smaller and sullen: registered as Dorner, Zita Maria, of Favoriten, formerly of Leoben, citizenship confirmed in 2009, identification issued at- It trailed off as if bored with itself. Someone had written these lower things for the benefit of the ordinary authorities, because there are always ordinary authorities, even here.

The black question mark seal on the back of the envelope was the question mark she had worn last week at her throat like a cheap charm. It had glimmered on the television light and said nothing and said everything. The quiz show had been called Who Is the Queen When There Are No Kings. Petra had sent three angry texts at different points during the broadcast, full of rhetorical fireworks. Magda had watched too, her lips pressed so tightly together she had tasted salt. The game’s host was a man with a mouth like a smile that someone had pulled across a surface with a finger wet with oil. He had spoken to Zita as if the two of them had known all along that she would win. And she had won. Of course she had. There had been a question about the most obscure species of cave salamander in Eastern Europe. A question about an eighteenth-century land register for a small patch of orchard two hours south of here. A question about a saint who had been invented. Zita had answered with a confidence that would have been arrogance if it had been human. And the lights had turned her hair into a night no one had ever really been in.

“She cheats,” Petra had said aloud, from the couch where she’d left her coat on as if that would cut her losses. “Not a little. Not elegantly. She picks the whole system up like a rug and shakes it until all the dust is her name.”

“She doesn’t need to cheat,” Magda had said, not because it was true but because some sentences are muscle memory. “She can’t resist being that way. It isn’t just winning, it’s winning in a way that makes the rules blush.”

Petra had snorted. “So, that’s good then: we’re dealing with a poet who also does receipts.”

They had laughed then, or something like it, with the thin knobble of fear at the back of their mouths. And later, when the show had ended with music that wanted to be a parade but had forgotten its costume, Petra had left for the tram with three pretzels tucked into her bag, two for the journey and one for her father who thought he loved salt and in truth salt had been politely tolerating him for years.

But the laughter was not here now. Zita’s letter lay on the kitchen table like a stone that had been given a pen to hold. The words had weight. Not just symbolic weight, the kind that could be conjured away by wit. The kind that pulled on everything around it like a gravity and a law at once. The cat touched the envelope with one paw, very lightly, as if it was a pond and might ripple.

“Battle?” the cat said, perverse. We still call it battle?

“It’s the word she chose.” Magda fingered the shape of the eight on the page and felt it hum. “Battle is old. It makes people think of shields. Better than duel. Duel attracts the wrong kind of attention in this country. Duel makes men who wore swords to dances feel invited.”

You can decline, the cat offered, knowing that this was more of a thought than a possibility. You can cast your lot into a hat and draw out a different life and insist it’s your own. You can refuse anyone who invites you to bleed for someone else’s ratings.

“She has linked it to the oath,” Magda said. “You see that. She framed it. She wants the kind of crowd that comes when someone says there will be an official thing with old papers under it. You know what they’re like. They bring sandwiches and lawn chairs. They bring portable applause.”

The cat slid onto the chair and stared at her until she looked away. The old oath had been many things. It had been a promise made when the country was the world's expert in mixed messages and empire. It had been reformulated when the country fell apart and then claimed itself again with a smaller table. It had been a way to ensure that disputes would not bleed into the city’s ordinary blood. If you had a quarrel that could not be left to rot on its own, you could bring it under the mechanical protection of a spectacle. So people would think it was about fame or entertainment. And the real thing could hide there, less likely to attract the kinds of curiosity that brought in knives you hadn’t counted on.

In the next building, someone dropped a pan. The sound made its way through the courtyard like a bird that had forgotten how to navigate. Magda folded the letter and then unfolded it, as if that would change the ink’s set.

After breakfast, Magda set about her work. Work is a word that wears a lot of hands. In her case it was translating—people brought her things written in the wrong century, and she persuaded them into the present. It was also consultation for those whose wrong things had turned themselves into consequences. Once she had unwound the plagues from a jar of jam that had been mislabeled by a mother-in-law who meant it to be preserves and not a curse. She went to a courtyard off Lerchenfelder Straße to pour three pails of dark poppy seed along a crack in the stone, because the crack had something to say and could not get a word in otherwise. She visited an old woman downstairs who made schnapps in her bathtub and who had seen in the steamy mirror the face of a boy she had loved in 1944, which had not been as romantic as it sounded. The woman asked Magda to dismiss the boy with kindness. Magda did and then took a small bottle of schnapps anyway, because kindness is not incompatible with collecting your fee in a reasonable form.

By midday, the sky over the city was a uniform white and the light was returning from everything it touched. She drank soup out of a mug, and the spoon slipped and clanged in a way that suggested a symbol if you were inclined to collect those. Petra sent another message. omg did you see. of course you did. come here if you want to watch me swear before dinner. i have beer. Also a cheese with a rind that frightens me and might have to be negotiated with.

Magda typed: Eight o’clock, your place, I’ll bring bread and olives. Have you got garlic? And then she didn’t send it, because the afternoon had taken a turn and seemed to be listening. That was foolish, to ascribe intent to an afternoon. But foolishness is also a language, and sometimes it makes a kind of sense that logic doesn’t have pockets big enough to carry.

She opened her laptop and then closed it and then opened it again. She looked up Zita Dorn. It was always a mistake to look too long at the faces of those who would become your enemy; they got into the grooves in your eyes and lived there. But not looking at a problem makes it less like a problem and more like an animal behind a thin, damp curtain. Zita’s official page opened in a crisp white. Photographs in which she wore red. Interviews from two years ago where her voice was soft and pilgrim-bright. A clip in which she was laughing, her hand on the host’s wrist as if to keep him from leaving his job. Rumors in forums, the kind that have users with names like ppatience_1968 and bigwolfvienna. One forum thread began: Did you see how she looked left before the salamander question? Classic sign someone was whispering through the wires. Another: She went to that school, you know. The one with the flag that doesn’t have a country. The one that teaches you to climb on roofs and talk to statues. The one that says publicly we share everything and privately we take.

Magda clicked and clicked and then stopped and rinsed her hands under the tap and felt the water change as it hit her skin, temperature an anecdote told to different fingers with different emphases. She thought about the time in the archive when a voice had spoken as if in a photograph, just a mouth with no face. She thought about the way some people learned to use a crowd as a cloak. She thought about the letter with its black wax seal and the old-fashioned phrase that had no particular allegiance: I extend you invitation.

How strange to be singled out by someone who preferred rooms with two hundred chairs made from one idea to rooms with a kitchen table she had done her taxes on three years running. How strange to be the person she had this week chosen, as if she had reached into a bowl and pulled a name that had been chewed.

At four, the bells from a nearby church rang with the frenzy that always made her think of the bells practicing becoming themselves. Magda watched a man on the opposite balcony water a plant with leaves like little silver spoons. He had three rings in his left ear and moved as if gravity was offering him polite suggestions.

She called Petra. “I recieved something,” she said, and winced at the way the wrong letter in the word made the sentence feel truer. “I received something. Both. From her.”

Petra inhaled in obvious italics. “A cake? A bomb? A bouquet that leans the wrong way?”

“An invitation. There is a seal. There is the number eight drawn like a serpent and the Prater wheel and cabin seven. She’s invoking the oath. She wants—” She stopped. It was always difficult to tell where wanting ended and insisting began in a person like Zita.

“We knew she would do this, Mags,” Petra said, voice practical in the way of a person who almost believed in pragmatism. “You told me last week—when she took the TV money from a question no one should have any business knowing—that she was making a shape. And you were right. She thinks she’s building a new stage, and we all must come in through the trapdoor.”

“Pretend to be a fool. Let her underestimate you. Wear a scarf that says you don’t have a plan.”

“I have never worn a scarf that says anything. That’s your trick.”

“I’ll bring the garlic,” Petra said. “And a small knife. And a larger one. And the book with the pages that go blank unless you hold it over steam. And Bruno’s left shoe. He swears it’s lucky and I long to be rid of it.”

“You will do none of those things,” Magda said. And they laughed, though in both their throats a piece of winter took up residence and refused to leave.

After they hung up, Magda took the envelope and the letter and the cup with sticky honey on its lip to the sink. She washed the cup with casual care and the envelope with meticulous disinterest. You never knew what lurked in glue. She dried her hands on the towel that had once been a shirt. Then she went to the tall bookcase in the corner of the living room, where the bottom two shelves were as haunted as cupboards could be without frightening the resident children. She pulled down a book about the old laws of the city, the ones etched in granite and in floorboards and in people’s mouths. The page for the oath of contests crackled when she opened it, as if someone’s hands had been there not long ago. There were notes in the margin written in a neat unsentimental script, her teacher’s hand, she would know it anywhere. A sentence bloomed in the margin like mold: If you must go, bring a person who loves you and wants you to win, not a person who loves winning and wants you to be their instrument.

Magda closed the book gently and looked at the cat. “You don’t love me.”

The cat blinked. I am not made of love or hate. I am made of the little pieces of noise at the edges of both. But I want you to live, because living is interesting, and because you have learned how to heat milk without scalding it. Also you arrange cushions in a way that benefits me.

“Thank you,” Magda said. “You are, as always, balm.”

She set the book back and took down another, a thinner one stitched in blue thread. The list inside was her list, kept too long and with too much care. How to prepare for a public duel in a private city. Things to bring. Things to leave behind. She had written it when she was twenty and had thought she knew where the edges were. She read the items as if they belonged to another person and decided that the other person had not been entirely a fool.

When evening came, she took bread and olives in a paper bag and walked to Petra’s, because the tram was late and she had energy to spend. The sidewalks had that gloss that happens when the day freezes back into itself. People were wrapped in their coats and in their voices, talking about the football match, about their mother’s elbow, about the number of tourists at the cathedral this afternoon. Three children chased a half-deflated ball, which made a sound like a curse every time someone’s foot nicked it just so. At the corner, a man with a portable radio held it up so that everyone passing would hear the news and perhaps buy one of the wallets he had laid out on a blanket that had seen—better days, worse days.

Petra lived on the third floor of a building with a lift that had opinions about mass. Her hair was pulled up with a pencil. She opened the door as if she had been waiting for an hour, and likely she had, likely she had been pretending to rearrange a shelf while listening with her whole skin for footsteps. They embraced in the doorway without the ceremony of hello.

“I brought brine,” Magda said. “And three kinds of foolishness. They may be indistinguishable.”

“I have beer,” Petra said, leading her into the kitchen where a slim TV perched on a stool as if it were a pet that had chosen that spot. “And a cheese with a rind that looks like something the forest did after thinking about it too much.”

They arranged the food as if a little ritual had been promised and would be delivered. They didn’t talk about the letter right away. They were both old enough to allow joy to go first into the room whenever it broke in late.

The program started with a jingle, silly and knowing. The host came out in a blue suit the shade of tile in pools that are heated a little too much. He grinned the way some buildings lean. The audience clapped as if somebody had pressed a button, which someone had. The first contestant looked like a person who knew how to calibrate instruments on an airplane and was at peace with that. The second was an old woman whose smile could have sold knives. The third was Zita.

She wore black, the simplest kind, the kind that swallowed the definition around it. Her hands were ringless except for one thin band of metal on her left thumb. On the thumb’s band: engraved, the tiny fish-shaped question mark. Her hair was pinned back with tiny red lacquered clips that would have looked like clownfish if anyone had been close enough to say so. Her mouth was not a wound or a promise; it was something else, and Magda had learned a long time ago that not every mouth had a metaphor that could be fetched like a dog.

The game unspooled with the precision of something that had been drilled until it had become muscle. Zita answered in a voice that had been taught to be both modest and inexorable. She did a demure smile after a particularly implausible question—the kind of smile that said even the air was on her side. Petra swore in long strings under her breath, as she had promised, in a dialect that belonged to a village that had only ever existed when her father sang.

They watched until the beer was warm and the bread was gone and the olives were only pits and brine. “She’s moving the line,” Petra said when the credits at last climbed the screen. “There’s what’s allowed, and there’s what you can get away with, and there’s what becomes the new allowed because no one grabbed your wrist when they should have.”

“She’s also having the time of her life,” Magda said. Sometimes that mattered. Mostly it made people cruel. Power is bored by those who aren’t having fun. That was a rule she had found written on a wall once, and she had remembered it because it had been written in handwriting that looked like laughter attempting arithmetic.

“I hate the way she looks into the lens as if choosing someone.”

“She was,” said Magda, and the kitchen fell out of its chair for a second. “She chose me this morning.”

Petra put her elbows on the table and used her big hands to hold her face up so that feeling could have somewhere to happen. “We will write a letter back,” she said. “We will make it formal. We will use phrases that make anyone reading cough and say the word custom with hatred. We will remind her that just because a thing is a spectacle doesn’t a make it a carnival. We will-” She ran out of will.

“We will go to the Prater,” Magda said softly. “On the eighth day. Because she has used the oath and the wires.”

Petra looked down at the table. There were small rings of oil where the olives had been. The rings had arranged themselves into a symbol Magda recognized and decided to forget immediately. “You do not have to do this alone,” Petra said.

“The law says bring no one. You know it. The public is the witness. The cabin itself is the officiant.”

“Then we will not go. You will invoke some exception written in that book with confusing marginalia.”

Magda shook her head. “If I decline, she will make meals out of that. She will cook me with the idea of me. She will say: The people who owe you keenness are not keen.”

“Then we send someone else. Someone who has no skin.”

“We are short on friendless ghosts this week. I checked the rota.” She smiled and then didn’t.

Petra reached across the table and took Magda’s hand. The kitchen performed its trick of being the whole world. “Listen to me,” she said, voice a riverbed. “Win or lose, hon-” She stopped herself. Names acquire talons when you load them with hope. “We know what she is. We know what you are. You are not a fair person, Magda. I mean that as praise. You are not too fair to survive out there. But you are the kind of honest that has teeth. She will not have counted on that.”

Magda squeezed Petra’s fingers. The knuckles had a map printed on them, of every year’s winter. “I will write her back,” she said. “I will accept.”

“You will eat a slice of cheese for courage, even though the rind is telling me it has seen things, and those things were late and worrying.”

Magda laughed, and then a kind of fog lifted. She did eat the cheese. It tasted like the inside of a bell. She tasted iron and memory and the way cows in summer stand under trees and consider what shade is. The beer had gone flat and warm, but she drank it anyway because rituals like to be completed even in small ways.

She walked home under a sky that had decided to be starred. It was not a showy decision. The stars were more like a rumor, pinholes in the cloud where someone had pressed hard with a needle. At the Prater the giant wheel was a half-moon of lights in the distance, a necklace someone had taken off and hung on a nail. Cabin seven. Eighth turn. Eight bells. She tried not to do math with it. She tried not to make it into a nursery rhyme. She tried not to be thirteen again, telling herself that if she turned twice and then didn’t look down when crossing the bridge she would keep her mother living one more year. She tried not to remember the smell of the hospital, that lemon disinfectant and between it something that no one talks about.

Back in her kitchen, she took paper and a pen that had belonged to a man she had gone to bed with three times and then never called again because sometimes kindness is knowing when you should be selfish. She wrote:

To Zita Dorner, of whomever and what place.

I received your letter. I accept your conditions, because they are mine too, because we live here, because the bell rings the whole city whether you thought to or not. The Prater. Cabin seven. The eighth turn after eight bells. The witnesses will come and all their eyes will be mouths.

I will come with what I am. No more, no less. I trust you will too, despite your habit of collecting extra pockets.

A small drawing bloomed at the bottom of the page without her having decided to. It was a fishhook bent into a question mark, and under it she drew a straight pin. They were two letters, if letters could be forged.

She sealed the letter with candle wax because she had run out of the black kind years ago and because using red would be a waste. She resisted the urge to put anything else in there with it. A pinch of salt. A clipping. A hair. Resisted and then changed her mind and slid in three mustard seeds because sometimes love is making sure you can recognize your own letter if someone decides to toss it into a pile.

At the door she hesitated. The mailbox? The post? The small boy with the large ears who was always sitting on the steps trying to sell someone a tiny painted soldier from his grandfather’s cupboard? In the end she set it in the general outbox to the underworld, which is to say she slid it into the crack between the lift and the world and listened until a roll and a sigh told her it had gone to the place where such letters go.

She slept badly. Dreams came that pretended to be useful but were really advertisements. In one, she was in the quiz show chair, and questions rose around her like bubbles, and instead of answering she reached out and popped them one by one. In another, she and Petra were children, throwing rocks at a wheel because it wouldn’t stop turning. In the last, the letter became a bird and pecked her ear until she bled black wax.

In the pale morning she woke to the sound of a bicycle bell. The cat had discovered a way to look offended and innocent at once. There was flour on the table from nowhere, and on the flour a thin line as if a finger had written a word and then erased it. She made coffee with hands that were steadier than they felt.

Eight days. That was long enough to teach a muscle a new trick. That was not long enough to become a new animal. She would practice how to stand in a cabin that moved and made motion a rule. She would practice how to answer questions with her eyes. She would practice how to hand back a cheat. She would practice; then she would improvise; then she would choose when to be selfish.

On the second day a small box came to her from a woman she did not know, the kind of stranger whose mouth makes strangers into neighbors before they have earned it. Inside the box, a deck of cards with no faces. You drew a card and the blanched surface said something you had meant to say yourself. On the third day, the woman downstairs asked for her schnapps back because she had a date with someone as old as she, and nerves required fortification. On the fourth day, a child on the street ran past Magda with arms extended and whispered, as if reciting, “Cabin seven.” Children pick up things with their ears and then carry them across town because they have pockets that don’t stay empty. On the fifth day, the quiz show did a special episode where no one won and the audience was asked to stand and applaud randomness. On the sixth day, a crow landed on Magda’s windowsill with a bottlecap in its beak, and she took it and set down a piece of the cheese rind, and the exchange was good and made them both think better of the world. On the seventh day, it snowed.

Snow in Vienna is a complicated moment. It is both romance and complaint. It is both an opera and a line at the bakery. Magda watched it fall as if the city had decided to be dandruff. The cat pawed at the flakes where the window was warm and the cold made them elaborate. Magda took out her old coat, the one with the pockets she had once hidden a field in. She whispered to it, and it whispered back with the sound of moths changing their minds.

On the eighth day, Petra came at seven in the evening. They had made no plan to meet. They had always made the same plan without making it. When a person you love is going to be deliberate with danger, you hold their coat while they put their arms in. Petra braided Magda’s hair as if it was a rope they would both climb. She put something into the braid that glittered with a specific temperance. It didn’t matter what it was. It mattered that Petra’s hands had done it.

“We are going to a fair,” Petra said, voice so wry you could have sharpened a knife on it.

“We are,” Magda said. “A very old fair where once men bought prizes made of glass and pretended they were immortal.”

They walked. The cold held them in both its hands and squeezed gently, as if trying to figure out how they fit. The paths into the Prater were dark in the way that cities make, light pooled in the wrong places, shadows doing creative work between. The wheel rose ahead. Cabin seven was not magic; it was a wooden box with windows and hinges that had known every kind of weather. There were people there already, of course. People who had brought their winter hats with pompoms and their phones and their whispered verdicts. Spectacle, always, had babysitters and bystanders, and they did their jobs with varying degrees of professionalism.

A woman with a clipboard and a lanyard, the natural predator of the Vienna bureaucrat, approached. “Names,” she said aloud. She looked at Petra, at Magda, at the cat now nowhere, because the cat had other plans that did not involve being counted.

“Magda Rieder,” Magda said, and the woman’s pen skipped briefly as if it had learned the name in another life and had to exert itself to write it properly.

“Contestant,” the woman said, checking a box. First word: small, second word: big. Then her eyes moved right and left, eyes that had mastered the universal code of either I'm bored or I am extremely alert and would prefer you not know it. “You know the rules,” she added, without kindness and without threat. It was the tone of a tram driver at midnight who has seen two hundred variations of the same problem and expects nothing except someone to stand too near the door.

“I do,” Magda said. “I know all the rules, even the ones you won’t say out loud because they partly belong to the ground we are standing on.”

The woman nodded as if that was a correct answer. She pointed to cabin number seven with a pen that had the show’s name printed on it. Someone had covered the name with tape. It was supposed to be anonymous; that was the fiction, anyway. Zita stood a little apart, wearing a coat that looked like an argument made into fabric. Her face was turned up to the wheel as if she were saying grace. When she saw Magda, she smiled with just her teeth. The smile made it clear she’d eaten something no one had offered her.

“Wonderful,” Zita said to the air. “We are all here. The list can relax; the night can begin.” Her eyes flicked to Petra and then away, as if to say: I have chosen our positions; you will stand where I put you in my thinking. Petra folded her big arms and made the statue of an angel that guards bridges.

People moved as they were told to move by signs and by the choreography of crowds who have seen other crowds and learned those dances. The bell in the clock near the carousel began to ring. Eight, with the kind of measured certainty that was a prompt and a prayer. The wheel creaked as the operator, who had seen more nights than rules, set it in motion. Cabin seven opened its mouth.

It was warmer inside than Magda expected. There was a winter’s worth of breath caught in the wood. The windows were clean in the careless city way—someone had considered washing them and then been interrupted by an old man telling the story of a thing he had seen here when he was a boy, which had not been a true thing but had been told and told until it had the privileges of truth.

Zita stood across from her, the cabin closing them into a slice of the sky. There were no chairs. There was no host with a grin. There were two microphones installed late and a camera eye set into the corner like a fly too well-fed to buzz. The city fell away beneath them in a slow, inevitable drop. The wheel took its first turn.

“Welcome,” Zita said softly, to Magda, and to the camera, and to the bell as it finished singing and took a breath. “Finally.”

Magda said: “I would have preferred to meet in a kitchen.” She let the words be plain. She let them go without their armor. “But of course kitchens are not where you gather power these days, are they.”

Zita laughed and turned her head slightly so that a lock of hair fell like a poet’s first metaphor. “Oh, kitchens still matter,” she said. “Men fear them because they cannot control them. That hasn’t changed. But yes. I prefer the circles that people draw by accident when they sit with their mouths open. I like to be in there when the mouth makes shapes.”

“You cheat,” Magda said.

Zita’s lips parted in a small oh that was neither surprise nor offense. “Cheat is a word made by people who were late to breakfast and want to own lunch. I take the thing you take and I carry it better because I don’t apologize while I do.”

“This isn’t the show,” Magda said. “Names matter.”

“Then say mine with the old pronunciation,” Zita said. She leaned closer as the cabin rocked and righted. “Say it like you know where the letter belongs in your throat. Say it like you met a woman on a road and took her hand and told her it wasn’t her fault she loved winning. Say Zita Dorner, of no one and everywhere. Say it and then show me your pockets, Magda Rieder. The audience adores pocket checks.”

The wheel rose, and the city beneath them widened. The Danube lay like a promise in the distance, and the buildings were a chessboard that had mislaid four pieces and pretended not to notice. A small boy waved at the cabin from below, a red hat in a moving crowd.

Magda took a breath and let it out. She spoke then in the old way, the way that promised both spectacle and law, words that had been smoothed by tongues long dead. Her mouth was dry. Her knees were steady. Zita listened with her head tilted as if an unfamiliar bird had settled on the windowsill and begun to speak politics.

When the first question came, it came from the speaker in the ceiling, the voice that had held the show together for weeks. It asked something about a crown and a year and a piece of parchment that had considered itself the boss of people who did not consent to be bossed. Zita’s eyes flicked left in that little way that meant someone elsewhere had not been disciplined in their desire to help. Magda watched the flick and felt a movement in her own skull, something like a coin slid under a shell in a game that had never once been fair, and she did not reach to move it. She waited, and then she spoke, and the word she said was the wrong answer on purpose, because sometimes you win by moving the circle a little bit away and making the other person step where there is no floor.

The cabin lifted. The city did not care that it held them. The camera eye watched and did not blink. The wheel went around once as if testing both of them, and then went around again, and Magda realized that the night had teeth, and she was in its mouth, and the only way out was either through the tongue’s kindness or by becoming something even a mouth could not quite manage to hold. She smiled without showing her teeth, which is to say she looked like herself entirely. And downstairs, in the cold, Petra looked up and folded her arms and sent a thought that did not need a grammar to be understood: Do not let her rearrange the furniture inside you. Keep the table where we put it. Keep the knives where they hang. Keep the salt in a pinchable place.

The wheel took its eighth bell as if bells could be counted by mechanical grace and by blood at once. The city shifted its consciousness in small ways; people who had not planned to turn their heads turned them. Though the cabin was a room and the room was ordinary, though the air was thin and smelled of paint and old cedar and winter, though laws were being invoked and eyes were being fed, there was a moment when Magda could have sworn the sky itself leaned in to see. That might have been a trick of the wheel. It might have been Zita’s doing. It might have been exactly what it felt like: the world noticing, briefly, that someone had come to battle with both hands open and their pockets empty but full of other things entirely.The first answer laid itself down like a playing card that meant nothing by itself and everything in sequence. A small light by the camera changed color, the kind of meek red that means both recording and apology. Somewhere under their feet a relay accepted the error and carried it away on its little back. Zita’s mouth made a shape it had rehearsed for wrongness—sweet surprise, and a microsecond of pity—then let it fall. Magda kept her gaze fixed on the seam where the window met the wood. A smudge there had the exact shape of a fingerprint, or of a country that had been erased from a schoolbook and kept lingering on children’s tongues anyway. The voice in the ceiling cleared its throat with the expensive sound of something that had been told not to cough and did so with gravitas instead. The wheel groaned; the people below became smaller and better behaved; and the cabin crossed a corner of the sky where clouds had left a thumbprint too.

“Second,” said the voice, and this time it carried the crisp new-paper smell of a question that wanted to be respected by people who had learned to frown over their coffee. “When the rights of contest are invoked under municipal ordinance 18, subsection c, what advantage is afforded the petitioner in the matter of scope?” The language had the smugness of a clerk who has never once spilled ink. Zita’s eyes did the little flick that had enraged the forums. It was so tiny that it could have been a blink taught better manners. Magda exhaled slowly until the window fogged, then lifted her hand and wrote a letter there that was not a letter, the arc of a circle begun and not completed, a sentence friendlier than punctuation. In the fog, the question was visible the way breath sometimes makes visible the thing the air had been trying to say without lips. “Scope is a kind of famine,” she said. “When you say scope, you mean the right to choose the field and the instruments, and the petitioner is granted the choosing so long as they declare the extent in public. The advantage is theater. The advantage is called a crowd.” She did not say c. She did not say ordinance. She said the words that belonged to the floorboards.

“It is more technical than that,” Zita murmured, eyes still soft, voice for the camera’s sake a little breathless as if the altitude had been wheedling her. “It is measured. We measure it. We make it measurable. That’s what it means to live like this instead of in the weather.” The light shifted behind her and turned the coast of her cheek into something a painter would later misremember as devotion. “Scope means my hand gets the compass and yours gets the pencil.”

“Then you set the radius,” Magda said, because letting someone else name the length of a circle is the fastest way to be walked in. “Don’t forget the floor knows where the nails are.” She tapped the wood with the toe of her boot. Once, twice, and then once again in time with the sound the city makes when a tram’s wheels hit a defect in the rail and decide to make poetry out of it. The voice accepted her answer because it had to—the old languages, when spoken with the right temper, obliged the new mechanisms to dress themselves in different clothes. Outside, the wheel found the top of itself and did what tops do: noticed the falling.

Third came dressed in the innocent clothes of biography, the kind you buy in a stationer’s shop where the owner keeps an old dog under the till. “Give the derivation of your name,” the voice said, with a friendliness that had been calculated, and somewhere below several people turned to each other and did the thing crowds do when invited to feel the intimacy of someone else’s history. Zita looked delighted. She had told this story already on late-night radio, had told it with a little choke of throat, had named a grandmother’s kitchen, had described a child, herself, insisting that she would not be a Maria because Maria was a wall in a church and she wanted to be a doorway. Magda could feel Petra’s disapproval like a warmed coin in a pocket; naming is old magic, and hearing someone do it prettily for strangers is like watching a child sell her hair to a man who promises a wig. “I was Magda for a woman who had no children and a lot of violets,” she said before Zita could speak. “Rieder because somebody liked the way the sound leaned. The papers will tell you another thing and they won’t be wrong, but papers never bent down to pick up a dropped spoon, so I don’t take their word as the only word. The derivation is this: a woman in a market put a hand on my head when I was an infant and said, That one is stubborn, and stubborn walks like Magda. And my mother, who had damaged a dictionary once and never trusted reference after that, said, Yes.” She let the story sit there, not because it was a shield but because it had weight and weight is often a better defense than sharpness. Zita’s lips tightened in a way that was elegant if you did not know what it meant to want to be the only person who knows how to turn a key.

The wheel passed a strut white with frost. The cabin, as if in sympathy, gave a small semitone of complaint that might have been wood asking for oil or might have been old rules asking for courtesy. Between the spokes, the city flipped its pages, each square of light in an apartment a chapter in a bad or excellent novel. Magda pressed her fingers together and felt the small buzz she had trained herself to notice when wires brought whispers. It came from the corner behind Zita, thin as the idea of sugar in coffee ordered black. She looked not at Zita but at the little metal plate by the ceiling where the microphone had been bolted after some meeting where a man said words like deliverable and activation. There is a clause, she remembered, that says the air must be unowned during a contest. It is not called that exactly in the book, because the old book lets you pretend that the air belongs to no one without stating plainly that anyone who tries to own it must be slapped in public. “Breathe with me,” she said suddenly, not to the woman across from her but to the glass. She drew a circle again with her breath and finished it this time. Below, Petra must have felt the draft of the thought because she took in a breath so large that three people near her turned to see if she had been startled by a ghost. A moment later one of the attendants reached up on the outside of the cabin and slid a latch, old-fashioned and unapologetic. A window opened the width of a palm. Air came in that had been out of doors long enough to forget the rules. Zita frowned. Her shoulder twitched. The flick to the left looked less like a twitch and more like an unpracticed shrug. The whisper line suffered, which is to say it met weather and did not like it.

The next question wanted to sound ancient, but it had a stain where you could see the modernity had bled through. “Name,” the voice said, and the microphone seemed to enjoy the sound of the single syllable so much that it stretched it out like dough. “Name the patron saint of false witnesses unmasked.” A murmur went up from below from those who had watched the episode where a saint had been invented and then paraded past people who needed to believe in something convenient. Zita’s smile snapped into place with the tidy cruelty of a clasp. “Ludmila of the Latch,” she said, because she had given the saint that nickname herself and had dressed a statue in a film of approval and sugared curiosity. “She’s not real,” she added, smiling to the camera as if she were being generous. “But neither is the difference between truth and proof when the room is watched closely enough.”

“There is no saint,” Magda said, “but there is a street where someone has painted a door that opens only when the weather wants you to go through.” She had seen it last year, off Neustiftgasse, where the houses lean in to listen to men in hats talking about football and sorrow. “If you stand there and ask to be allowed, an old woman will tell you if you deserve it. If you lie, she will laugh until the lie falls out of your ear and lands on the pavement to be stepped on by a passing tourist. That’s who you are talking about and you know it. Don’t pour sugar on it and call it holy.” She hadn’t meant to be unkind, but sometimes a sentence comes wearing boots. Zita’s eyes cooled. “Incorrect,” said the voice from the ceiling, not because it was wrong—streets require faith—but because the apparatus had no way to register a thing that was not carved on paper at City Hall. “Accepted,” said the wheel beneath them, because the wood remembered more than the ordinance.

Turn two fell away and turned to three. The cabin did its little forward-hinged bow to gravity each time it crossed the top. Magda thought of the mustard seeds she had slid into her envelope and wondered if they had found their way into a pocket near here and if they were doing what seeds do best: being patient and waiting to be asked. Zita shifted her weight and the coat she wore made a very soft sound, like silk being reminded of a past life. “Do you know,” Zita said conversationally, as if they were two women in a queue and not two people teaching a wheel a lesson, “the first time I lied on purpose? I mean in the way you object to, where the lie is a tool, not a color? I told a teacher that I had hurt my hand so I couldn’t write, and she let me speak. I liked speaking. I liked it so much I learned to hurt what was in the way of it.” She said it as if it were gospel. The camera drank her face. The people below, who had not come for a confession but would settle for anything fed to them with confidence, leaned closer without moving. “That is not a question,” Magda said. “It is the right shape to be a question if you shaved two pieces off and tilted it a little to the left, but it is not one. Are you allowed to ask me to admire you in the middle of the law?” She put a small smile on the side of her mouth where jealousy sometimes sits; she offered that smile to the wood of the cabin rather than to the woman.

The voice went on, dutiful as a man with a tray of drinks. “Under the older formulations, contestants may each proffer a question once, under seal.” The word seal made both of them look, involuntarily, at the place in the letter where the black wax had pretended to be old. Magda felt a prickle along her forearms, as if a choir of bureaucrats had cleared their throats in unison. She had been saving her one. In her pocket someone else’s pen was warm. She could feel Petra’s hands in her hair pulling through the braid and tucking in the small glittering thing that did not matter and also mattered a great deal; the glitter was a piece of broken glass taken from the floor of a hotel where a different contest had gone wrong; it was a reminder and a compass both. “I proffer,” she said, and the wheel hummed a little differently because a proffer is an old word and pleased a mechanism that had once been maintained by men with cigarette ash under their nails. “My question is for the officiant.”

“You cannot—” said Zita, which was a way of saying she did not like to be asked to share authority with an object. “I can,” Magda said gently, “because the officiant is a thing that notices. We agreed to that when we chose this place. The giant wheel belongs to the city because everyone owes it a small piece of their childhood and their fear of height. That’s the legal phrasing under the paint.” She put her hand flat against the wood. It was warmer than she expected, as if a thousand winter hands had left kindness there. “Officiant, ask.” She made of the word not an order but an invitation like the ones she had been taught to write on the breath so that old stones would feel included.

It took a second. Machines, even old ones, have pride and do not like to be hurried into intimacy. The voice from the ceiling tried to speak and then did not. The camera tried to tilt and then did not. A small change came through the floor, as if the axle had shifted its thought from rotation to attention. The question rose through the wood like sap. “What do you owe me,” asked the wheel, and its voice was not a voice but a sound she recognized from summers when the metal had been hot enough to smell. “What do you owe to the thing that holds you up while pretending to let you fly? Say what you owe honestly.” It was not poetry; it was not legal; it was the kind of question that refuses to be arraigned by cleverness. Zita’s mouth opened and then closed. Magda could feel heat behind her own eyes and in the angle of her jaw. She thought about the day her father had lifted her into a cabin and she had decided to be brave because he hated that she was frightened and she loved him in the complicated way children love people who want them to be different. She thought of climbing higher than she could justify in a courtyard once, up iron that rusted on her palms, and how the view from the clothesline had made her both generous and petty at once.

“I owe you my balance,” she said to the wheel in a voice that felt like the first swallow of a winter drink made of spices and apology. “I owe you the grit under my boot. I owe you not to throw anything over the side and call that letting go. I owe you to know the difference between floating and being carried. I owe you thanks for the moment when you go slow at the top to make a child feel like God.” She had not expected the last sentence, and when it arrived it undid something tight just below her ribs. Zita looked at her with a complicated expression that could have been contempt and might have been recognition, which is worse.

Zita’s answer came with the steadiness of someone who understood performance and had trained herself to hate confessed need as a road to hunger she could not control. “I owe you money,” she said first, and several people below laughed in the relieved way crowds do when a line is thrown like a bone. “I owe you my best angle. I owe you to behave in your cabin so you keep letting me in. I owe you nothing else.” It would have been an answer in a more ordinary place. The wheel considered. It had long since learned not to expect gratitude, but it liked to be addressed as a thing with a job. The wood thrummed underfoot. The cabinet with the camera in it twitched, embarrassed to be seen judging. Magda felt the relief that comes when a place has taken your answer and not spit it back in your face as if you had spoken nonsense to a tree.

The voice upstairs, startled into mortal duty, returned. “Fourth,” it said, but it sounded scuffed. “There is a clause concerning measures of silence. Recite it.” Zita spoke quickly to get back on the part of the map where she knew where to put her feet. “Silence must be equal when it happens; time without speech is counted and carried over. You cannot starve someone with quiet. That’s written.” Her thumb rubbed the ring it wore, and the fishhook question mark flashed in the cabin’s electric light. Magda thought of the three mustard seeds again. She could smell faintly, under the cedar, a bitterness. It might have been her imagination; it might have been the way winter makes sometimes of people: small gardens growing in the wrong places.

“We owe each other to leave some of it unsaid,” Magda added, because clauses are improved by mercy when they are remembered out loud. “We owe each other to leave room for what can’t be said to sit down without being asked to dance. That is the part the book leaves out, but the city knows it. If you press your ear to the statue by the Rathaus long enough, the stone will say the same, and the police will shrug and pretend not to notice you being peculiar because you are not hurting anyone.” The voice did not accept or deny. It had begun to understand that arguing with the ground was bad for its warranty.

The fifth came flavored like arithmetic, which was Zita’s field, even if the numbers she liked best were ratings and not sums. “Eight is not only a number,” Magda said before the question could finish posing itself as an ordinary invitation to count. “Eight is the way two circles decide they will not be lonely.” Zita made a noise as if to swat away a fly. “Eight is the law’s vanity,” she said, and the camera adored her again because contempt always photographs like glamour. “It is the way you draw infinity when you are too tired to stand upright. It’s not magic; it’s an agreement. We agreed to this one. We could agree to a nine and call it better because it looks like a person who has stopped pretending to be a serpent.” She had a point. She often had points. It had made her able to cut through cloth she had not woven.

Below, the man who ran the wheel scratched his ear with a key, and Petra leaned in and said something to the clipboard woman in the careful tone of someone asking politely for a door to be opened that must be opened twice. The clipboard woman listened with all the disdain good clerks carry like an umbrella, and then moved toward a panel and pressed her thumb there for exactly as long as it takes the human body to remember a time when food was not guaranteed. The cabin jolted. Wind that had been working hard all afternoon was admitted in a gust that ignored show business. Zita’s hair loosened by a piece. She did not reach to fix it, which Magda admired because pettiness is catching and she was trying not to be infected tonight.

“Sixth,” the voice said, running now, because someone somewhere had told it the world preferred momentum. It asked the sort of thing you kept in the pocket of an exam: list three protections afforded to the ordinary citizens in the case of spectacle, and to whom they are to petition for relief. Zita looked so bored for a moment that Magda could see the girl she had been before the world learned to clap for her. “Earplugs,” Zita said. “Safe exits. The right not to be filmed if they raise three fingers and keep them up. Petition goes to the officer in the bright jacket who pretends not to be a priest, or to the operator who pretends not to be God, or to the woman with the clipboard who is God’s intern.” It was a good answer because it was not wrong; it was wrong because it kindled nothing gentle in the room; and the wood did not bother noting the difference because it had seen much worse and did not have the bandwidth for didactics.

Magda added the thing the books had footnoted only in the older editions, the ones printed when ink smelled funny and pages stuck together in damp weather. “They can also petition the crowd,” she said, and felt the murmur below change as people remembered that safety sometimes is only that: looking sideways and deciding to be the voice that says no when no is needed. “Three people shouting is a petition. Ten is a rule.” She glanced at Petra without moving her head. Petra stood with her feet apart and her big arms folded and her face a geography of stubbornness and love. The woman with the clipboard, to her credit, did not roll her eyes. She had been doing this too long to refute common sense.

There was time moving around them that did not stay in place like normal time. It was the time of waiting rooms and of lovers holding their breath and of the space between a lit match and the first lick of flame. When the seventh came, it came like a coin you drop on purpose because you want to hear if it clinks the right way. “Question,” said Zita then, stepping in where the voice had been about to. It was her proffer. Her eyes were bright with a hunger that had belonged to her since she was small and had been told to eat less of herself. “Why did you stop?” she asked in a tone scraped free of the sugar she used for television. “Not the job. Not the little jobs. The big one. The one people come into back rooms to talk to you about. The one with the saints and the stairs and the why-don’t-you just join us and stop pretending to be a civilian. Why did you stop doing the work the way we do it?”

There was a sound then that had nothing to do with the wheel. It was the small dry noise of a thing inside your chest that has been looked at without being warned. Magda opened her mouth and closed it and opened it again, a hinge that had not been oiled recently. She thought of her teacher’s hand in the margin with its neat notes and its sentence about the person who loves you and wants you to win. She thought of a year when she had gotten too good at the trick where you leave a room with everyone believing they had won. She thought of a night on a roof when she had said yes to something and then had woken in the morning with the word no under her tongue like a pill you are supposed to swallow without water. “Because fair and kind are not the same,” she said finally. “Because I am not fair and I am particular about that. Because the room where you do it is hungry in a way that makes me cruel. Because appetite makes me stupid and I liked being less stupid. Because my mother died and I discovered that if I kept winning while being the kind of person who kept winning, the grief had nowhere to sit, and it started to shiver in public. Because I found out I liked kitchens better than stages and could not persuade myself that this was an improvement some days. Because.” She did not wrap it in a bow. The wheels of the city carried a distant siren along.

Zita watched her the way a person in a closed carriage watches the weather through a crack, searching for a meaning beyond dampness. “I thought it would be something uglier,” she said, almost disappointed. “I brought uglier answers with me. I packed them carefully.” She had. They showed under her coat like gashes she had drawn in shadow where no one could touch them without taking her side. “Your turn,” she added fiercely. “Ask a sharp thing and see if I bleed in a way the audience will clap for.”

Magda had a sharp thing ready. It sat in her mouth and tasted like a coin that has passed through too many hands. The wheel creaked and told her they had one more turn before the eighth. She could ask something that would make Zita say a name, and the name would be currency, and Magda could spend it in all the ways she had promised herself she no longer enjoyed. Or she could ask for generosity and make a liar of herself and a fool too, and fools do not survive these rooms unless the room is merciful and the wheel was a machine, not a god. She thought of mustard. She thought of three tiny seeds in a pocket warming by a body. She thought of how seeds do not care why they are carried; they care only for when. “Who taught you to cheat?” was what the crowd wanted. “Who taught you not to be gentle?” was what a better person would say. She surprised them both and herself. “What did you leave behind,” she asked softly, “when you walked from Leoben? The first thing. Without telling yourself a story about why.”

It was a question with a hook in it. Place questions can be refused, but they leave splinters. Zita’s face went very still. Her eyes did the little flick not toward a wire but toward something inside her head that had a very small child’s room in it. “A ring,” she said at last. She made the sound of a person swallowing not pride but a small burst of contempt for her former self. “Very thin. It belonged to someone who told me to wait in a way that made waiting feel like being put in a cupboard. I left it on a post by the bridge with a bus to Vienna due in twelve minutes. I told myself I would come back for it and then I did not.” It was ordinary. It was not ordinary at all. Somewhere below, someone with a romantic disposition clutched at a chest that had weathered three wars and a renovation, and told the person beside them a story about the time they had left something small and metal in a place where rain could find it.

The eighth came over them like a coat you have loved without cleaning too often. The bell at the carousel measured it. The wheel took it slowly because it had been asked a good question and had been given two answers that fit more or less into the holes the world had left in their respective bodies. The camera whirred the way a small animal whirs when it is asleep and dreaming of running. The voice had a penultimate thing to say, because of course it did: “Final. Declare your instrument.” It was an archaic requirement from the days when men said sword and pistol and had eyelashes so long they cast shadows on their cheeks in oil paintings. The modern version was a formality that usually produced words like intellect, charm, grit, and team. Zita lifted her hand. “Audience,” she said, with a frankness that was almost tender. “I have become what I am because you want what I am and I am not ashamed of having learned to be it. You are my instrument. That is a compliment and a theft.” Her voice softened on the last word in a way that would make very many people forgive her.

Magda placed her palm against the cabin again. “Place,” she said. “I am an instrument when something notices where it is being asked to happen. Streets. Kitchens. Wheels. That and the way names sit in the mouth. And the way coffee hands over what it learns when it passes through ground. And the person who braided my hair. And the person who has never once asked me to be smaller so they could feel taller. Those are my instruments.” She did not look down when she said person. She did not say Petra’s name. She had learned that names in these rooms grew teeth and would chew up your foot if you dangled it too close to the floor. The wood under her hand was warm now enough that she could feel the pulse of the axle through it, a small repetition like the word yes when said by someone who rarely uses it.

The wheel slowed. The world below was still the world, which meant you could buy roasted chestnuts if you wanted and watch a horse drag a cart of beer with a dignity that would have made old Dukes jealous. The cabin slid into its lowermost thought. The latch was readying itself for home. “Verdict,” the voice said, hungry to be done before it embarrassed itself by seeming human. Magda watched Zita’s shoulder blades under her coat move as she took a breath to tolerate the sensation of being weighed by anything other than her own need. The crowd arranged its faces into listening. The man with the key scratched his ear again because habit is a kind of shelter.

What the wheel would say was none of the camera’s business, not for that moment. It belonged to wood and to the law and to the wet breath of a million people who had stood and kissed and fought and eaten in the radius of its shadow. It had one job left: to make the eighth turn contain not only motion but a memory that would attach itself to the two women in the cabin in a way neither of them could pick off later and call stain. The bell in the carousel sang one last time with all the formality of a civil servant who knew his work was delicate even if his tools were crude. The cabin rocked. The latch lifted its chin. The wind lifted hair and then laid it down.

“Hold,” said the wheel quietly, not to the voice and not to the camera and not to the people. It was a word it had learned from brakes. “Hold and know.” The door did not open yet. The turn took its time. Magda smiled without showing teeth again, because it was all she knew to do at the edge of the idea of an ending. Zita’s hand went absently to the thin ring on her thumb, and for the first time since stepping into the cabin she looked like someone who had been small and alone and then had put on a coat and practiced three faces until they obeyed. Down below, Petra licked her thumb and drew a circle on the wood of the wheelhouse and finished it, and made a face at the clipboard woman, who did not see but would be aware later that a kindness had happened near her in a way that made her day more possible. And far up in the steel, in a place where no one cleaned because no one could reach, something small and black with bright eyes peered down and thought about the heat of language and about the way questions, like kettles, know when to sing.The door remembered its job before the voice did, and in that half second Magda thought she felt the hinge consider the moral weight of opening. The wheel had said hold, and because it had been built by men who trusted their hands more than anything that called itself a system, it obeyed its own command without waiting for permission. There was a sympathetic hush from below that had nothing to do with production and everything to do with bodies understanding that a thing was deciding something in their presence. Zita’s eyes did their small private arithmetic and came up briefly empty, which made her beautiful and terrible in a way that would have moved an older painter to start a new school.

“By scope declared and place acknowledged,” said the wheel at last, and the voice from the ceiling transcribed as best it could, a clerk being asked to take dictation from weather. “By breath given to air that was being told how to behave. By the old municipal courtesy that pretends to be shy and is not. Contest is incomplete because instrument was overbroad and because wire whispered in a room that promised silence.” The words were not words, not how courts make them, and yet they came as sentences do when you have trained your mouth to be reliable. The camera panicked and steadied; somewhere a producer swallowed a series of noises that would have gotten him fired if he had let them become audible. Petra smiled so slightly that only the woman with the clipboard, whose job had taught her to notice small resistances, saw and pretended not to.

“What does incomplete look like,” Zita asked, and to her credit she put no sugar on it, no tilt of the chin to indicate she would turn even an insult into inventory. Her hand had left the ring and returned to it; you could tell only because her thumb was blushed pale where the metal had pressed. Magda felt the cat’s absence as a shape and guessed, without needing to look, that the bright-eyed thing high in the iron had been her inconvenient familiar deciding to experience the city from a place we pretend is only for pigeons and maintenance men. The wheel creaked once, as if it were warming itself to the work of an answer no one had asked it in a hundred years.

“Incomplete means return,” the wheel said, and the bell across the square answered with a single tongue against bronze, an involuntary amen. “Two turns hence the cabin will open again in the presence of those who insist on witnessing. Petitioner’s advantage is halved by the speaking wire and will be made equal by the thing under glass called a kitchen, in a room the respondent names. Between now and then, neither may speak aloud the name of the other in public, under penalty of poor luck in small matters and a mildew that chooses its own corners. Questions may be asked of place, not of person, and place will answer if it wants to. Instruments are declared and will not be traded without notice. Hold and know.” It was bureaucratic in the way storms are bureaucratic—they have procedures, they follow them, they do not tend to write reports.

“So we are scolded and sent to wash our hands,” Zita said quietly, and she looked, for a breath, like a girl being told dinner is at six and she must earn it by setting the table. The glare she sent the camera was so small most eyes missed it, but the machine did not, and it shivered in its casing like a dog that has learned to fear a certain tone. Magda let out a breath she did not know she had been hiring to keep her spine straight. She didn’t look at Petra. Looking at Petra now would send a thread across the cabin the way children once strung string between two tin cans and pretended the voice came clean; that thread would be cut by the thing that called itself spectacle and then wrapped around their throats like an ornament.

The latch gave up its resistance, and the door prepared to return to being a door instead of a mouth. The crowd made the communal decision to applaud, but because the verdict had not been a verdict, the sound hiccuped into something like polite laughter and then sorted itself into a warm, complicated noise that could not be put on a showreel with confidence. The woman with the clipboard wrote a word Magda could not see and then wrote another and then underlined both with the concentration of a person who understood that underline was not merely emphasis but conjuration. The operator, whose name would never be printed anywhere because he had the caution of someone who had once watched two boys climb under the wheel without knowing what they were playing with, scratched his ear again and muttered to the lever. The lever, instructed by a thousand nights of work, ignored him with respect.

“Two turns hence,” Magda said, because even when a machine had spoken it, the sentence wanted a human mouth to register properly in the air. She softened the words as she sent them out, a habit learned in courtyards where doors have learned, through long acquaintance with refugees and salesmen, to open only for certain kinds of wind. Zita’s mouth took its neutral expression back as if taking off a hat that had started to itch. “Fine,” she said, and the fine was so thickly varnished with acceptance that no one saw the splinters under it unless they were looking hard. “I hope your kitchen is clean. I hope your knives have no ghosts.” It was not a threat. It was a professional courtesy expressed in blade length.

They stepped out and the cold took both women equally, which pleased Magda in a childish way she did not mind indulging just now. The first few rows of the crowd—those who had decided to have faces and names tonight rather than be a generality—leaned in as if expecting autographs on the air. A man whose day job was selling budget insurance on the phone said aloud to his companion that he had never realized how much the Ferris wheel sounded like the organ at St. Roch’s when the priest was new and enthusiastic. Petra reached Magda just beyond the circle the clipboard’s lanyard had declared sacred and temporary, and she did the thing you do when you have no ritual prepared for what you must acknowledge: she touched the back of Magda’s head just above the nape, as if to reassure the hair that it had done correctly staying braided.

“You were yourself,” Petra said in a tone that refused to put frosting on praise. “She was herself too, which is a pity because I sometimes wish people like her would be other people on Tuesdays. The wheel was an old bureaucrat who discovered for a second it could have a soul, and then remembered it had to be at work again in the morning. Do we drink something that burns or something that sweetens your mouth enough to keep you from biting anyone who comes near you on the tram.”

“Burn me and then sweeten me,” Magda said, and it made Petra bark a laugh that sent three small birds off the roof of the nearby ticket kiosk. The woman with the clipboard approached then with the look of someone whose job required delivering information to people who might choose to eat the information and the messenger both. She held out a folded paper in a plastic sleeve with a stamp that did not exist outside the city’s secret drawers. Her eyebrows did not bother attempting sympathy; her mouth had never practiced it.

“By the office that watches the oath,” the woman said, and she did not apologize for the office, which was good manners, “you are notified that the second session will be permitted as declared if you furnish the address within twelve hours. Kitchens must comply with ventilation standards. The device with the camera will be admitted if it remembers to be respectful. The wire will be tested for silence with a bowl of water and a spoon. If the spoon moves, the bowl goes out the window and the broadcast loses its rights for a quarter under section nine. Sign.” She had two pens and offered the nice one first. Magda took the less nice one because there are small resistances she will never give up.

“I will send the address in an hour,” Magda said, and she felt Petra’s arm solid beside her, a post a horse might be tied to without humiliation. Zita took her copy and did not look at it; she slid it into the pocket inside her coat that had been sewn by hands that knew this was where a person kept the documents they could not afford to lose. She caught Magda’s eye then and allowed herself a brief grinning: the grin was a truce flag made of foil, attractive and disposable. “I hope you cook first,” she said. “I dislike kitchens that pretend to be museums. And I hope your neighbor upstairs does not practice a tuba on Thursdays because the camera is allergic to tubas.” She turned away before either of them could answer, because control depends on the appearance of never waiting to be dismissed.

They did not take the tram. The cold made the air something you could lean on, and the walk back was a way to unknot ankles that had tried to understand a moving room. Petra bought chestnuts from a man who had burned his fingers so often he had lost the habit of flinching. The paper cone warmed their palms through their gloves, and the smoke underlined the night with a line of text streetlights could not parse. A boy ran past and shouted into the ice, “She’s going to fight in a kitchen,” with the joy of someone who had learned a new rule for a game he planned to cheat at and win honestly anyway. The boy’s mother followed and said his name—and because names are spells, he slowed and let her catch his sleeve without complaint.

“There is a spoon that knows too much in my second drawer,” Magda said, as if they had been discussing shopping lists all along. “It will tell stories to the bowl until the office becomes embarrassed and praises its compliance with a stamp. I will choose the big pot with the dent, because I do not trust pots that are confident. Will you come at seven and pretend to be a person who is just here for salt.” Petra nodded as someone who had already planned the morning’s thefts and kindnesses might. “I will bring bread and nothing sharper than my tongue,” she said. “The cat will sit on the fridge and criticize your chopping. Bruno will try to come and pretend to fix something so that he can be present for posterity and write about it in his small ugly notebook. I will tell him there is a fee for men with notebooks and watch him go home briskly.”

In the stairwell of her building the light did its midnight trick of arguing with the timer, and they climbed the last flights in a glow no one had paid for. The cat was sitting on the table as if it had been paid to supervise and was willing to accept late payment in fish. Its ears said three rooms had said unwise things while they were gone and two had made soup.
