The wheels of the city carried a distant siren along.

Zita watched her the way a person in a closed carriage watches the weather through a crack, searching for a meaning beyond dampness. “I thought it would be something uglier,” she said, almost disappointed. “I brought uglier answers with me. I packed them carefully.” She had. They showed under her coat like gashes she had drawn in shadow where no one could touch them without taking her side. “Your turn,” she added fiercely. “Ask a sharp thing and see if I bleed in a way the audience will clap for.”

Magda had a sharp thing ready. It sat in her mouth and tasted like a coin that has passed through too many hands. The wheel creaked and told her they had one more turn before the eighth. She could ask something that would make Zita say a name, and the name would be currency, and Magda could spend it in all the ways she had promised herself she no longer enjoyed. Or she could ask for generosity and make a liar of herself and a fool too, and fools do not survive these rooms unless the room is merciful and the wheel was a machine, not a god. She thought of mustard. She thought of three tiny seeds in a pocket warming by a body. She thought of how seeds do not care why they are carried; they care only for when. “Who taught you to cheat?” was what the crowd wanted. “Who taught you not to be gentle?” was what a better person would say. She surprised them both and herself. “What did you leave behind,” she asked softly, “when you walked from Leoben? The first thing. Without telling yourself a story about why.”

It was a question with a hook in it. Place questions can be refused, but they leave splinters. Zita’s face went very still. Her eyes did the little flick not toward a wire but toward something inside her head that had a very small child’s room in it. “A ring,” she said at last. She made the sound of a person swallowing not pride but a small burst of contempt for her former self. “Very thin. It belonged to someone who told me to wait in a way that made waiting feel like being put in a cupboard. I left it on a post by the bridge with a bus to Vienna due in twelve minutes. I told myself I would come back for it and then I did not.” It was ordinary. It was not ordinary at all. Somewhere below, someone with a romantic disposition clutched at a chest that had weathered three wars and a renovation, and told the person beside them a story about the time they had left something small and metal in a place where rain could find it.

The eighth came over them like a coat you have loved without cleaning too often. The bell at the carousel measured it. The wheel took it slowly because it had been asked a good question and had been given two answers that fit more or less into the holes the world had left in their respective bodies. The camera whirred the way a small animal whirs when it is asleep and dreaming of running. The voice had a penultimate thing to say, because of course it did: “Final. Declare your instrument.” It was an archaic requirement from the days when men said sword and pistol and had eyelashes so long they cast shadows on their cheeks in oil paintings. The modern version was a formality that usually produced words like intellect, charm, grit, and team. Zita lifted her hand. “Audience,” she said, with a frankness that was almost tender. “I have become what I am because you want what I am and I am not ashamed of having learned to be it. You are my instrument. That is a compliment and a theft.” Her voice softened on the last word in a way that would make very many people forgive her.

Magda placed her palm against the cabin again. “Place,” she said. “I am an instrument when something notices where it is being asked to happen. Streets. Kitchens. Wheels. That and the way names sit in the mouth. And the way coffee hands over what it learns when it passes through ground. And the person who braided my hair. And the person who has never once asked me to be smaller so they could feel taller. Those are my instruments.” She did not look down when she said person. She did not say Petra’s name. She had learned that names in these rooms grew teeth and would chew up your foot if you dangled it too close to the floor. The wood under her hand was warm now enough that she could feel the pulse of the axle through it, a small repetition like the word yes when said by someone who rarely uses it.

The wheel slowed. The world below was still the world, which meant you could buy roasted chestnuts if you wanted and watch a horse drag a cart of beer with a dignity that would have made old Dukes jealous. The cabin slid into its lowermost thought. The latch was readying itself for home. “Verdict,” the voice said, hungry to be done before it embarrassed itself by seeming human. Magda watched Zita’s shoulder blades under her coat move as she took a breath to tolerate the sensation of being weighed by anything other than her own need. The crowd arranged its faces into listening. The man with the key scratched his ear again because habit is a kind of shelter.

What the wheel would say was none of the camera’s business, not for that moment. It belonged to wood and to the law and to the wet breath of a million people who had stood and kissed and fought and eaten in the radius of its shadow. It had one job left: to make the eighth turn contain not only motion but a memory that would attach itself to the two women in the cabin in a way neither of them could pick off later and call stain. The bell in the carousel sang one last time with all the formality of a civil servant who knew his work was delicate even if his tools were crude. The cabin rocked. The latch lifted its chin. The wind lifted hair and then laid it down.

“Hold,” said the wheel quietly, not to the voice and not to the camera and not to the people. It was a word it had learned from brakes. “Hold and know.” The door did not open yet. The turn took its time. Magda smiled without showing teeth again, because it was all she knew to do at the edge of the idea of an ending. Zita’s hand went absently to the thin ring on her thumb, and for the first time since stepping into the cabin she looked like someone who had been small and alone and then had put on a coat and practiced three faces until they obeyed. Down below, Petra licked her thumb and drew a circle on the wood of the wheelhouse and finished it, and made a face at the clipboard woman, who did not see but would be aware later that a kindness had happened near her in a way that made her day more possible. And far up in the steel, in a place where no one cleaned because no one could reach, something small and black with bright eyes peered down and thought about the heat of language and about the way questions, like kettles, know when to sing.

The door remembered its job before the voice did, and in that half second Magda thought she felt the hinge consider the moral weight of opening. The wheel had said hold, and because it had been built by men who trusted their hands more than anything that called itself a system, it obeyed its own command without waiting for permission. There was a sympathetic hush from below that had nothing to do with production and everything to do with bodies understanding that a thing was deciding something in their presence. Zita’s eyes did their small private arithmetic and came up briefly empty, which made her beautiful and terrible in a way that would have moved an older painter to start a new school.

“By scope declared and place acknowledged,” said the wheel at last, and the voice from the ceiling transcribed as best it could, a clerk being asked to take dictation from weather. “By breath given to air that was being told how to behave. By the old municipal courtesy that pretends to be shy and is not. Contest is incomplete because instrument was overbroad and because wire whispered in a room that promised silence.” The words were not words, not how courts make them, and yet they came as sentences do when you have trained your mouth to be reliable. The camera panicked and steadied; somewhere a producer swallowed a series of noises that would have gotten him fired if he had let them become audible. Petra smiled so slightly that only the woman with the clipboard, whose job had taught her to notice small resistances, saw and pretended not to.

“What does incomplete look like,” Zita asked, and to her credit she put no sugar on it, no tilt of the chin to indicate she would turn even an insult into inventory. Her hand had left the ring and returned to it; you could tell only because her thumb was blushed pale where the metal had pressed. Magda felt the cat’s absence as a shape and guessed, without needing to look, that the bright-eyed thing high in the iron had been her inconvenient familiar deciding to experience the city from a place we pretend is only for pigeons and maintenance men. The wheel creaked once, as if it were warming itself to the work of an answer no one had asked it in a hundred years.

“Incomplete means return,” the wheel said, and the bell across the square answered with a single tongue against bronze, an involuntary amen. “Two turns hence the cabin will open again in the presence of those who insist on witnessing. Petitioner’s advantage is halved by the speaking wire and will be made equal by the thing under glass called a kitchen, in a room the respondent names. Between now and then, neither may speak aloud the name of the other in public, under penalty of poor luck in small matters and a mildew that chooses its own corners. Questions may be asked of place, not of person, and place will answer if it wants to. Instruments are declared and will not be traded without notice. Hold and know.” It was bureaucratic in the way storms are bureaucratic—they have procedures, they follow them, they do not tend to write reports.

“So we are scolded and sent to wash our hands,” Zita said quietly, and she looked, for a breath, like a girl being told dinner is at six and she must earn it by setting the table. The glare she sent the camera was so small most eyes missed it, but the machine did not, and it shivered in its casing like a dog that has learned to fear a certain tone. Magda let out a breath she did not know she had been hiring to keep her spine straight. She didn’t look at Petra. Looking at Petra now would send a thread across the cabin the way children once strung string between two tin cans and pretended the voice came clean; that thread would be cut by the thing that called itself spectacle and then wrapped around their throats like an ornament.

The latch gave up its resistance, and the door prepared to return to being a door instead of a mouth. The crowd made the communal decision to applaud, but because the verdict had not been a verdict, the sound hiccuped into something like polite laughter and then sorted itself into a warm, complicated noise that could not be put on a showreel with confidence. The woman with the clipboard wrote a word Magda could not see and then wrote another and then underlined both with the concentration of a person who understood that underline was not merely emphasis but conjuration. The operator, whose name would never be printed anywhere because he had the caution of someone who had once watched two boys climb under the wheel without knowing what they were playing with, scratched his ear again and muttered to the lever. The lever, instructed by a thousand nights of work, ignored him with respect.

“Two turns hence,” Magda said, because even when a machine had spoken it, the sentence wanted a human mouth to register properly in the air. She softened the words as she sent them out, a habit learned in courtyards where doors have learned, through long acquaintance with refugees and salesmen, to open only for certain kinds of wind. Zita’s mouth took its neutral expression back as if taking off a hat that had started to itch. “Fine,” she said, and the fine was so thickly varnished with acceptance that no one saw the splinters under it unless they were looking hard. “I hope your kitchen is clean. I hope your knives have no ghosts.” It was not a threat. It was a professional courtesy expressed in blade length.

They stepped out and the cold took both women equally, which pleased Magda in a childish way she did not mind indulging just now. The first few rows of the crowd—those who had decided to have faces and names tonight rather than be a generality—leaned in as if expecting autographs on the air. A man whose day job was selling budget insurance on the phone said aloud to his companion that he had never realized how much the Ferris wheel sounded like the organ at St. Roch’s when the priest was new and enthusiastic. Petra reached Magda just beyond the circle the clipboard’s lanyard had declared sacred and temporary, and she did the thing you do when you have no ritual prepared for what you must acknowledge: she touched the back of Magda’s head just above the nape, as if to reassure the hair that it had done correctly staying braided.

“You were yourself,” Petra said in a tone that refused to put frosting on praise. “She was herself too, which is a pity because I sometimes wish people like her would be other people on Tuesdays. The wheel was an old bureaucrat who discovered for a second it could have a soul, and then remembered it had to be at work again in the morning. Do we drink something that burns or something that sweetens your mouth enough to keep you from biting anyone who comes near you on the tram.”

“Burn me and then sweeten me,” Magda said, and it made Petra bark a laugh that sent three small birds off the roof of the nearby ticket kiosk. The woman with the clipboard approached then with the look of someone whose job required delivering information to people who might choose to eat the information and the messenger both. She held out a folded paper in a plastic sleeve with a stamp that did not exist outside the city’s secret drawers. Her eyebrows did not bother attempting sympathy; her mouth had never practiced it.

“By the office that watches the oath,” the woman said, and she did not apologize for the office, which was good manners, “you are notified that the second session will be permitted as declared if you furnish the address within twelve hours. Kitchens must comply with ventilation standards. The device with the camera will be admitted if it remembers to be respectful. The wire will be tested for silence with a bowl of water and a spoon. If the spoon moves, the bowl goes out the window and the broadcast loses its rights for a quarter under section nine. Sign.” She had two pens and offered the nice one first. Magda took the less nice one because there are small resistances she will never give up.

“I will send the address in an hour,” Magda said, and she felt Petra’s arm solid beside her, a post a horse might be tied to without humiliation. Zita took her copy and did not look at it; she slid it into the pocket inside her coat that had been sewn by hands that knew this was where a person kept the documents they could not afford to lose. She caught Magda’s eye then and allowed herself a brief grinning: the grin was a truce flag made of foil, attractive and disposable. “I hope you cook first,” she said. “I dislike kitchens that pretend to be museums. And I hope your neighbor upstairs does not practice a tuba on Thursdays because the camera is allergic to tubas.” She turned away before either of them could answer, because control depends on the appearance of never waiting to be dismissed.

They did not take the tram. The cold made the air something you could lean on, and the walk back was a way to unknot ankles that had tried to understand a moving room. Petra bought chestnuts from a man who had burned his fingers so often he had lost the habit of flinching. The paper cone warmed their palms through their gloves, and the smoke underlined the night with a line of text streetlights could not parse. A boy ran past and shouted into the ice, “She’s going to fight in a kitchen,” with the joy of someone who had learned a new rule for a game he planned to cheat at and win honestly anyway. The boy’s mother followed and said his name—and because names are spells, he slowed and let her catch his sleeve without complaint.

“There is a spoon that knows too much in my second drawer,” Magda said, as if they had been discussing shopping lists all along. “It will tell stories to the bowl until the office becomes embarrassed and praises its compliance with a stamp. I will choose the big pot with the dent, because I do not trust pots that are confident. Will you come at seven and pretend to be a person who is just here for salt.” Petra nodded as someone who had already planned the morning’s thefts and kindnesses might. “I will bring bread and nothing sharper than my tongue,” she said. “The cat will sit on the fridge and criticize your chopping. Bruno will try to come and pretend to fix something so that he can be present for posterity and write about it in his small ugly notebook. I will tell him there is a fee for men with notebooks and watch him go home briskly.”

In the stairwell of her building the light did its midnight trick of arguing with the timer, and they climbed the last flights in a glow no one had paid for. The cat was sitting on the table as if it had been paid to supervise and was willing to accept late payment in fish. Its ears said three rooms had said unwise things while they were gone and two had made soup. It examined the plastic sleeve, sneezed with disdain, and then turned its attention to a small draft coming from the window where the seal was insufficient in winter and wonderfully permissive in spring. “We will host a part of the city,” Magda told it, because houses like to be informed when they are about to be asked to perform. “We will wash, and we will hide certain things in the drawer you cannot open without pebbles and a curse, and we will leave the sugar where it can save a sentence that wants to curdle.”

She wrote the address on a card made for doctors’ waiting rooms and slid it into the envelope the clipboard woman had left. She wrote the words in a hand that did not want to be read by people who intended to argue about kerning. The kitchen looked at her then, the way kitchens look, with a severity born of having seen every kind of human attempt either to keep promises or to abandon them with style. She said aloud that she was grateful for the stove’s stubbornness and for the way the water in this building sometimes ran brown for three seconds and then fixed itself without being asked. Gratitude is a lubricant as well as a salve; the pipes hummed with the satisfaction of being seen.

She did not sleep. That was not a decision but a weather system. Petra, who could fall asleep against a wall in a well-lit station while a man with a violin practiced murder beside her, installed herself on the couch with her boots off and announced in a conversational voice how many tiles were on the ceiling if you counted only the whole ones. The cat prowled the dawn, which arrived bruised and unrepentant. Letters slid under the door with the practiced insolence of the city; one was from the office, stamped and official like a promise made by a person you love and slightly do not trust; one was a postcard from a woman in Croatia who sent Magda listless drawings of shells; one was a flier for teeth whitening that had stolen its font from a revolution. Magda drank coffee and then tea and then water and thought about the word incomplete until it became a gift rather than an insult.

At eight in the morning a municipal employee whose badge had sat muttering in a drawer for weeks rang the bell. He carried a bowl, a spoon, a checklist, and a look of long-suffering professionalism that had become in him almost an art. He was small and fastidious and looked like a person who had resisted becoming somebody’s father only to discover late that fatherliness came in other forms and had found him anyway. “I am here to test your air for opinions,” he said, and he didn’t smile because he did not want to be the kind of civil servant who made light of the work. “The spoon must move only when invited. The bowl must not tremble. You must sign, and if you cheat I will tell your grandmother.” Those lines were written and had been handed to him; he had learned to deliver them without bitterness because bitterness curdles spoons.

Magda brought him into the kitchen with the respect due a priest who had renounced all gods but holds the power to declare your bread legal tender. He set the bowl on the table, which tried not to remember the black wax mark. He placed the spoon in the bowl with a gentleness that implied he had once, perhaps as a boy, spoken to small river creatures and expected them to answer. “There will be a question,” he said, studying a stopwatch as if it owed him an apology. “When it is asked, the spoon will want to argue. You will not let it. Are you ready.” Magda looked at Petra, who refrained from making the spoon laugh by telling it a story about a man in a bar who had mistaken his own reflection for a friend. “We are ready,” Magda said, and the cat, on the fridge, sighed as if to say it had seen this trick and found it theatrically effective but narratively lazy.

The voice from last night was piped in thinly through a device the inspector set on the table, a cylinder of metal perforated like an old theater voice. It asked a dull question, something about ordinance subclauses that would put an inkpot to sleep. The spoon twitched. The bowl did not. Petra put two fingers lightly on the table as if soothing a nervous horse. Magda drew a circle only in her head and did not finish it, a courtesy to a spoon that had not asked to be a proxy for ethics. The spoon considered humility and decided to be cooperative today. The inspector clicked his stopwatch and nodded once, the nod of a man whose job at last goes as intended, a relief so rare it felt foreign.

“Compliance noted,” he said, filling a small square on a larger square with ink. “Your kitchen smells like someone who can translate sadness into soup, which is not on the form but should be. At fourteen hundred hours the technicians will inspect your outlets for spirits. If they find any, they will leave them outside in a jar, and you can keep them if you wish. They have learned not to make friends with what they harvest because of an incident in Ottakring involving a boy who fell in love with a draft. At nineteen hundred hours the recording equipment will arrive and then your privacy ends until we write it down that it begins again. Please have mercy on the crew. They eat badly, and it makes them mean.” He packed the spoon and the bowl away as if tucking a child into a stroller and let the clock in his body sweep him back into the city.

The day stretched itself across the building. The woman upstairs did not practice the tuba; instead she played a song on a piano that had suffered for its art and came through the ceiling like smoke. Bruno came and did try to fix something, as Petra had prophesied, and accepted the fee for men with notebooks with more grace than expected and retreated with his dignity intact and his notebook heavier for it. The cat disappeared and reappeared with a scrap of foil in its mouth as if making an offering to a god of artificial light. Magda cooked because cooking made the air rounder and less likely to pick up whispers and because you cannot lead a city into your kitchen and feed it nothing but rules.

In the afternoon, a young woman with hair dyed a decisive green knocked and presented a form in triplicate that demanded permission to film the hallway for transitional shots. She looked at the wall where a bicycle had scraped a bruise last year and saw in it a future scene where a woman walks away from a camera and everyone at home thinks, for a moment, that they could follow her and they do not. She kindly put blue masking tape along the floor where tripods must not stand because your neighbor downstairs had confessed she had once been stuck in a doorway while carrying three loaves of bread and had not recovered her courage. Petra brewed coffee until the room could balance on the smell alone. Magda moved knives around until their placement said respect instead of threat, and then she moved them again because superstition builds furniture and she wanted to be sure the chairs it made would not collapse under a polite person.

Evening approached like a neighbor who knows whether to borrow sugar or to bring cake. The crew arrived carrying cases that looked like coffins for small robots. The camera flinched when it saw the stove as if remembering last night’s small glare and wanted to apologize without using language. The man who monitored sound had ears like shells, and he wore a hat that had decided already how long it planned to remain on his head. He tested the walls by tapping them with a knuckle and listened to the returns as if listening for a tone only he knew the names of. He asked whether there had ever been a child crying in this room for two hours while someone did something with apples, and when Magda said yes he told the wall to behave because echoes love to think they are the most important people in the room.

At seven, the woman with the clipboard came with a new clipboard, which suggested the old one had been sent to a drawer to calm down. She read the formality that hung between them like a curtain and let it drop. The city was in the doorway now. It had taken off its hat. It wanted to be fed and adjudicated and permitted to have an opinion that would not be punished in the morning. Zita arrived without a coat and without the expression she wore for stages. She was smaller in a kitchen, not because the room diminished her but because power has to change shoes when it crosses thresholds. She looked around as if taking an inventory, then laughed once in the direction of the kettle, which had just then decided to whistle, a coincidence she chose to let become an omen.

“Welcome,” Magda said, and the word did something to the light. It made it warmer without making it brighter. She held out a plate because kitchens know what they are for, and Zita took a slice of bread as if it were a failure to admit hunger in front of witnesses. Petra nodded to her as a person nods to someone who has just explained their own burden honestly. The cat launched itself with practiced indifference onto the fridge and looked down as if judging a parade. Outside the window the world behaved; snow made a clean noise against the glass; a siren passed as if ashamed of needing attention.

The voice from the ceiling was humbler here. It had the sound of being poured out of an enamel cup rather than a goblet. “Two turns hence,” it said, obedient to the wheel’s arithmetic, and the operator across town touched the lever in the wheelhouse not because he needed to but because habit extends itself through the city when invoked. “Contest resumes, instrument declared. Scope halved and equalized by pot, knife, heat. Air tested compliant. Witnesses present. Officiant: place.” The camera tucked itself into the corner and tried not to cast a shadow that would make the chopping board anxious.

“What do we do, then,” Zita asked, and there was curiosity in it unadorned by a pose. The question made her more dangerous in the way a child with a stick becomes dangerous only when she learns it is a wand if you pretend correctly and ask politely. Magda looked at the book on the shelf with the blue thread and did not take it down because she had learned the temptation of reading the spell instead of being hospitable to it. She lifted a pot and set it on the stove so lightly the iron did not dare complain.

“We ask place to tell us what it knows,” she said, and she thought she felt the knot of the city move, the way a sleeping dog shifts and remembers that it is entrusted with entire rooms. “We will not ask about saints. We will not ask about ratings. We will ask the table why it remembers certain elbows and what they meant. We will ask the floor what footprints it has chosen to keep. We will ask the sink what it has refused to swallow. If you cheat in here, the coffee will burn you and the sugar will pretend to be salt and every parsley leaf will turn away from your knife. If I cheat, the cupboard will refuse to open and the matches will break, and Petra will not talk to me for two days.” She smiled then because she had almost made herself a liar on purpose by promising punishment she could not guarantee.

“Fine,” Zita said, and there was eagerness there she could not keep out. She put her palms on the table and did an old thing by accident; she asked blessing without pronouncing the word and the table, having seen worse, granted a provisional approval. The voice in the corner drew a breath for its opening and then thought better of it. The clipboard, endowed for the evening with something like a conscience, sat very still and did not tap itself against the woman’s leg.

Magda poured water into the pot and added salt and then did not count breaths because counting would make it a show and she had not invited show, despite the camera’s presence. She put onions on a board and cut them. She did not weep because she had wept last year and the onions recognized her as kin. Zita watched and did the respectful thing; she did not offer to help; she did not pretend ignorance; she let the knife make a conversation with wood and flesh and the green center of a sprig of savory. “Ask your first,” Magda said, because generosity is a resource and if you hoard it the pipes go dry. She kept her eyes on the knife as a courtesy to both of them.

“What is the oldest thing in this room,” Zita asked, and then, because the law required specificity, “that still remembers being something else.” Her voice sought the corners. It did not command. It waited. The kitchen, which had not been asked so directly in years if ever, rustled. The sugar made a small avalanche; the stove clicked twice. Petra, who had been born with a river running the length of her spine and a coal cellared somewhere above her heart, looked at the windowsill where a jar sat that had once held cherries.

“The towel,” said the room, and Magda startled a little that it had decided to speak aloud and not through muscle memory and the small adjustments that happen when you cook right. “The towel was a shirt,” the room said, “and before it was a shirt it was a tablecloth for a picnic where two people said unwise things under trees, and before that it was a sheet on a bed in a room where a man who had done everything badly once did one thing well and then tried to make a habit of it and failed.” The voice did not come from one point; it came from all the places where cloth remembers skin. The camera, poor creature, had no setting for this; it hummed in sympathy and hoped that sympathetic hum would be legible to the office later when the forms had to be justified.

“Second,” Magda said, and the onion consented to be browned rather than burned. “What does the sink refuse to swallow.” She knew the answer but asked because rooms like to be asked to say what they have been forced to tolerate. “Promises,” said the sink at once, and Petra clapped her hands once before remembering she was not here to applaud plumbing. “It spits them back. It will take blood if you let it, and it will complain and then forgive. But it will not take promises if you whisper them into the drain. They sound like bones trying to be whistles.” Zita made a sound that might have been a laugh and might have been a kind of surprise. She touched the lip of the sink, and then snatched her hand back without thinking because the lip had been warmed by hot water and domesticity, and she had expected obligation to be colder.

“Third,” the voice from the ceiling tried in a small way to re-establish its dignity. “Under the oath’s kitchen clause, both parties will now declare a memory of this place not told before to outsiders, to ground themselves in something other than performance.” The clause had been written by a municipal clerk who had once saved a child from choking by lying convincingly about the presence of a toy in the next room, and had then gone home and made soup with hands that would not stop shaking.

“I burned a pot,” Magda said, and it felt like a benediction because it was so simple. “It was summer. I was in love with a woman who liked to pretend that being late had been outlawed. I watched a sparrow on the windowsill and thought I could be someone different if I learned to stand still exactly as long as a small bird takes to assess a threat. The pot took offense at the neglect and became black at the bottom as if it had been reading some philosophy I disapprove of. I kept the pot because I wanted to have in this room a thing that would survive my attention wandering.”

“I slept on that floor,” Zita said, surprising them both, and the floor answered with a small creak as if to say it had been expecting to be brought in at the end, as a witness no one had bothered to list. “I slept here two years ago after a party. I did not know it was your floor. I did not know this was your kitchen. I woke up and ate something that had been left out on the table and confessed a lie to a jar and then told it to keep its mouth shut. It did. It was cherries.” The jar, flattered, adjusted its glass the way a very old person adjusts a collar when told they have done their hair correctly. Petra raised her eyebrows and then lowered them as if storing a question for a day when the city was less in the room.

On the stove, the water behaved. On the sill, the savory let go of its sting into steam. The city outside sat, attentive as a cat in a beam of sun, choosing for once to be the audience rather than the act. Magda tucked a strand of hair behind her ear that had escaped Petra’s braid and thought about how answers come differently in rooms that have agreed to receive them. Zita’s face had lost the small tension that television insists on; she was listening with vanity briefly in abeyance. The voice in the ceiling asked something important then, because even voices earn their keep on strange nights.

“Admit cost,” it said, and the cupboard door chose this moment to ease itself open, as if to agree that public accounting had its place. “Admit what you will pay if you keep being exactly who you are in rooms like this and in rooms like the one on the wheel. Do not be elegant. Do not weaponize it. Put it on the table with the bread and let witnesses decide whether they want to eat it.” The question had come out of an ordinance that had itself been born of a scandal with eels and a photograph and a judge who wore his sorrow badly; it had been shaped since then by people who had to put their names to papers that would outlive their bodies.

“My mother will keep dying in small ways,” Magda said, because she had never found a kinder way to put it even in her mind. “I will be thought difficult by men who want me to be gentle in exactly the way they are used to being consoled. I will be loved less often in public by people who do not like to applaud a person who refuses to give them the version with neat corners. I will write fewer invoices and more recipes, and the balance will become precarious. I will be boring on Wednesdays. I will be someone the city calls on when it is tired of being lied to and then forgets to invite when it wants a story told at a certain speed.” She set the ladle down and let the steam wash her mouth with the taste of salt that had not yet become soup.

“I will be alone unless I decide not to be and then I will be less good at the work I was made for,” Zita said, and her lip curled on the last words not because she did not believe them but because believing them had become an insult she liked to throw into corners. “I will be envied, which is a tax, and I will be punished, which is also a tax, and I will pay both because I like buying things that make other people uncomfortable. I will be wrong publicly once in a way that will be turned into a comic T-shirt sold by men with rucksacks and a contempt for women who are not their mothers. I will have nowhere to put tenderness except in places that do not deserve it or want to be seen doing so.” She held out her palms as if to show they were empty and the room in a very quiet way made them heavy with the small weight of flour motes and the larger weight of not lying.

The wheel, across town, felt the pot come to a boil and had an urge it rarely had in the winter: it wanted to stop moving and come into a room where women were using the correct verbs for their lives. The operator scolded the lever for being sentimental and drank his tea, which had been made irresponsibly strong by a niece who was trying to learn contempt from the radio. The bell at the carousel missed a beat and then remembered itself and pretended it had meant to.

“Verdict,” said the place, because even kitchens like endings when the soup is ready and the knives are arranged like well-behaved planets. It did not say who had won; it said instead what must happen if they insisted on continuing to make nights like this in this city where the rules sometimes are written on napkins and sometimes on marble and sometimes on beer. “Petitioner will not bring wires into rooms that answer. Respondent will not punish victory with scorn. Both will feed the witnesses. If you are to do this again—and you will, because the city likes it and your bones like it more than you admit—you will do it with the understanding that scope includes mercy and not only theater. The oath of contest is amended in this kitchen for the space of one winter and the width of this table. If someone disapproves, they may take it up with the wheel when it is in the mood to entertain complaints.” The clipboard scribbled as if trying to keep up and failing; the woman holding it made the face of a person told that an extra line must be fitted into a page already full.

Zita laughed then with something like gratitude braided into the sound, and even the cat forgave it. “So I am asked to win kindly,” she said, and she shrugged with delicacy and a certain ferocity, as if to say that kindness could be its own spectacle if taught to pose. “So I am asked to not build my throne out of knives and then call it furniture. I have been asked worse by people with worse rooms.” She took a bowl from Magda’s hand and accepted soup as if someone had awarded her a prize that had not been paid for by injury.

Petra, whose wrists had become spoons from decades of stirring when no one else would do it, pulled chairs out with the authority of a person who knows what to do with people exposed briefly to truth. The crew looked at each other as men do when told that their job will require them to be humans in a place that expects it and will mark them down for doing it wrong. The clipboard woman put the pen on the table and ate bread as someone who had been hungry and had not known. The city, at the window, fogged the glass and wrote a rude word and then wiped it off itself, embarrassed and entertained, because it had learned tonight that it enjoyed being asked to tell stories by rooms that knew the shape of a sentence before it was born.

They ate. The camera took what it could get and did not get in the way. The voice in the corner tried to remember a hymn and discovered it could not, which relieved it of a certain anxiety. Zita and Magda did not drink to each other because toasts are promises and they had already made one to place; they did touch the rims of their bowls together once in a gesture that belonged in a story Orpheus would have enjoyed if he had been born in a housing estate. Petra talked about nothing of consequence across the top of it all, which is to say she served as priest and entertainer both without acknowledging herself as either.

Later, much later, when even the city had fallen briefly quiet and the footage had been copied to three drives and labeled with words that would make no sense to anyone who had not had to testify in a room with fluorescent lighting, Magda stood alone in the kitchen in the kind of silence that had earned her regard. The cat rubbed its face along the leg of a chair, rendering it formally the cat’s property under a law no office had ever dared to write down. She looked at the pot, at the towel, at the bowl that had behaved for the inspector because it prefers to please when asked correctly, and she let herself consider the word incomplete again. It no longer tasted like defeat; it tasted like yeast, which makes things rise if you do not rush it and makes a mess if you do. She turned the clocks to face the wall and let the apartment catch its breath. She did not sleep. She did not need to. The night had been its own rest, a kind of work that, for once, paid her back in the currency she preferred: a room she loved being more itself because she had asked it to be.

By morning the city’s appetite for rules had sobered, and a thin light in the kitchen admitted itself with the caution of a clerk who knows both how to refuse and how to bend. The clocks were still facing the wall, which meant time had been asked to sit in the corner and keep its voice down. The cat had slept on the chair with its paws folded in a way that suggested piety and mischief had shaken hands, and its whiskers held the memory of steam though no kettle had sung for hours. Magda’s body had the particular ache given by nights that are both argument and feast. She stood at the window and watched the courtyard consider frost, which it did each winter the way some people consider religion: suspiciously and with an almost sensual calculation of inconvenience.

The papers did their part by not printing what had happened and letting their headlines behave as if truth would stain if handled improperly. A columnist wrote that the giant wheel had been unusually philosophical, which made three tram drivers in three different districts laugh at exactly the same minute, not because they had read the column, but because the wheel’s small squeal in the cold had hit a note that felt like gossip. A talk radio host made the mistake of saying someone’s name in the wrong spirit while describing a kitchen, and an hour later the studio found a damp luxuriance blooming under a light switch in the shape of a continent that did not exist. He took the hint and referred thereafter to “the arithmetic pilgrim” and “the woman with the stubborn towel,” which worked about as well as cheap maps work in fog.

There was a letter slid under the door that looked like a bill and smelled like discretion. The office that watched the oath had printed on municipal stock a thank-you that doubled as a warning. It suggested that kitchens, when asked to officiate, would henceforth be afforded the same protections as public monuments, with a footnote explaining that public monuments should try, when possible, not to sulk if draped briefly in scarves. It reminded all named parties in polite small type that in public spaces they must call each other “the petitioner” and “the respondent” or, failing that, “the person” and “the other person,” and that if they forgot, mildew would decide to take interest in the undersides of their wooden chairs. The letter offered a number to call in case mildew became ideological rather than housekeeping, which made Petra snort coffee ground-fine through her nose when she read it and earned the paper a place on the fridge until the magnet it clung to developed a sense of entitlement and slid off.

Magda’s phone swarmed with messages written by people who were not quite sure what they had witnessed and wanted to be certain they had not been the only ones. There were congratulations that tried to be unassuming and failed, admonitions that tried to sound intimate and tripped, and one exquisite note from a woman who wrote simply that she had for the first time in years refused to clap when asked even though clapping had been her habit and had kissed her husband in the doorway instead, because doorways had felt promoted. There were also two requests for appointments, one about a set of keys that had started to lock their owner out from the inside, another concerning a music box that played a march in reverse on Tuesday evenings and had begun, disconcertingly, to make a child’s footprints appear in flour.

She boiled water and made tea because coffee would have joined the morning too fast and tea was better at easing itself into a room and asking where the chairs liked to stand. The cat leapt onto the table in a movement that gave the lie to gravity and sat with the purposeful nonchalance of a foreman regulating a crew. It examined the stove, blammed its eyes at the window where a small feather had lodged between glass and frame, and then looked at her with that specific attention which means: I have been listening to the neighbors through the pipes and three of them were very unwise after midnight. “I am not here to scold anyone’s pleasure,” Magda said, and the cat flattened its ears in agreement that pleasure belongs to itself until it knocks asking at the wrong hour.

Petra arrived before noon with two loaves tucked under her arm and, in her coat pocket, a small roll of blue tape used by film crews to make the world behave for twenty minutes. She moved like someone who had slept on the couch and dreamed in straight lines for once. They kissed each other’s cheeks in the doorway without chatter because routine had a beauty that did not like to be decorated. “Bruno asked if you would autograph his fee,” Petra said, setting the bread down and turning her mug upright with the tenderness of a person who has loved and scolded a country into remembering how to be kind. “I told him that money is already an autograph and if he wanted more I would sign his shoe with a word that would embarrass him by its accuracy.”

“They are going to make a version,” Magda said, and what she meant was the show, the office, the city, the friends they had not chosen; all the entities that love an instance enough to turn it into a pattern and then to a brand. “They will ask kitchens to act natural and build sets that break your hip because realism measures differently on a spreadsheet. They will ask coffee to confess. They will sell the way onions brown.”

Petra tore a crust off the loaf and spoke into the crumb as if addressing a microphone with good manners. “Then we can be provincial about it,” she said. “No exports. The clause says one winter. The clause says the width of this table. Anyone who brings a crew into a kitchen without first obtaining permission from the towel will find themselves making soup with water that refuses to boil and parsley that declines to be chopped.” She swallowed, caught the cat trotting past with something crinkled in its mouth, and liberated the object, which proved to be another strip of foil embossed with stars that had escaped a chocolate. “He has begun to tithe,” she said, her voice admiring and affronted in equal measure. “He thinks the apartment is a temple and he is its complicated god.”

They walked out into the day because staying in would have taught the curtains to expect attention, and curtains with expectations become tyrants. The city had put on a pale blue and looked faintly cropped at its edges, as if some hand had trimmed the day to fit the frame of an old print. On the corner, a woman sold chestnuts that did not taste burned enough to be fashionable, which made them perfect. A bus sighed at a stop and confessed to three pigeons that it had been thinking about the mountains. Children had invented a chant that could get you in trouble in some places and a free sandwich in others. “Cabin seven, kitchen eleven,” they shouted, without knowing or caring what eleven had to do with anything; it rhymed and let the feet cut air into pieces, and that was enough.

Near the Prater they encountered the operator of the wheel varnishing a small section of wood as if applying balm to an old bruise. He nodded at them with the polite indifference of a person charged with caring for a thing that cannot repay him except by continuing to be itself. His moustache had been white since the last time any of them had thought they were forever. “Good working,” he said to Magda in the way of tradespeople who dislike making compliments into events. “It takes a particular wrist to get a thing built for forward motion to listen to something going on in a kitchen. She,” he added with a tilt meant to include the wheel and the city and the operator’s mother tongue and the current winter, “was proud to be asked.”

“She insists we come again, very possibly with soup,” Magda said, and the man grunted, which in wheelhouse dialect meant I will make the joints not squeal the next time if I can and not let the men with the signboards crowd too near the axle. Petra, without looking up, pressed her thumb to the balustrade and traced a circle she did not finish because old men with varnish notice things and she did not wish to be thought disrespectful. Somewhere behind them a tourist explained to another tourist that the wheel had once been dismantled and rebuilt and had decided not to bear a grudge.

By afternoon the forums had stacked themselves into a precarious architecture of opinion and rumor. Users with avatars depicting saints of their own invention composed long posts about the halving of scope and the way place had been invited to have a vote. One pseudonymous voice with a tone of ferocity disguised as grace wrote that the kitchen moment had been the first time she had watched the city be permitted to address its citizens without an intermediary, and she suspected the city had enjoyed it. Another, on a board frequented by men who liked to pass off nostalgia as policy, warned darkly that allowing places to speak would only embolden teapots to file petitions. A debate flared for twenty minutes about whether mildew was a classist penalty and whether chairs in poor neighborhoods would suffer disproportionately, and then subsided into a thread about which brand of soap offends saints the least.

At the office where the oath was kept in drawers and on rooftops, a meeting unspooled with fewer speeches than usual and more silence that did not embarrass itself. A man who had inherited his position from a woman who had not believed in inheritance said that they would tolerate kitchens as officiants so long as the rooms in question had at least one window, because rooms without windows make people say forever, and forever is a word that cannot afford to be shouted. A woman whose handwriting resembled a ladder wrote in the margin of a memo that they should set aside a small fund to repair table legs, not because of sentiment but because you cannot ask a piece of wood to hold up that much law and not splint it later. No one suggested making it a show segment. The office had learned long ago that when it tried to stage its own ceremonies the city laughed very gently and documents went missing from inside of things that did not have insides.

Magda collected three new tasks by simply walking down Mariahilfer Straße. One woman needed help persuading a pair of boots to agree that they belonged to this century and not to a grandfather who had walked himself into a war and out again with his smile rearranged. Another had brought home from a flea market a mirror so sure of its own opinion that it had refused to show her face unless she sang a particular lullaby, which she did not know and did not wish to hum in front of her bathroom because bathrooms remember. A third asked whether Magda could unstick the word please from the throat of her daughter, who had been born with ease but had learned in school that asking paints a target on your back. Magda said she could try the boots and would speak to the mirror and offered to teach the daughter how to use maybe instead and to set please aside for special occasions and persons of substance.

Their path took them past the café where two years ago a woman wearing yellow had told Magda that she was tired of being told that all the city wanted from her was her prettiest sigh. The same barista, a man with forearms like melted clock faces and a devotion to crema that suggested religion without rules, glanced up and gave them both a nod that not many people received, a rare species of benediction in this city that has learned to hoard them without malice. “Two,” he said, setting saucers like laws, “for the people who make rooms change their minds.” He then left them to it, as is proper when a gift is too subtle to be accompanied by commentary.

They spoke of naming because the penalty for public slip now had claws and humor. Petra referred to the other woman as the one with the out-of-season cherry pits, which made Magda laugh for the first time since the wheel had said hold. Magda confessed that she had almost said the name in the hallway to the inspector with the spoon and had only saved them both from mildew by swallowing the word like fishbone and then telling the wall she was sorry to be theatrical in the morning. Petra looked around the café, at chairs that point to one another like accomplices and tables that have learned to ignore all but the most vivid flirtations, and said they must agree on euphemisms and change them regularly the way spies used to change train stations. They shook hands solemnly on calling her the arithmetic pilgrim when in public and the pilgrim when they were in rooms that could bear eavesdropping. They agreed to call Magda the towel’s keeper when needed, and both of them enjoyed the way that sounded more dangerous than not.

The cat found them at the café, as it could in most places not explicitly infused with peppermint. It arrived at the exact height of the pane of glass most vulnerable to noseprints and made one, then sat on the outside table as if daring the city to pass a regulation. A crow hopped behind it and deposited a nail with intention, a small iron declaration of fealty, or perhaps barter. The cat accepted, chewed the nail in a way that would have horrified a dentist and pleased an ancestor, and then tucked it under the belly as if sitting on treasure in the only fashion available to a creature without pockets. The crow gave them both a look suggesting appreciation of the compact and then flew off, its wings spelling a word that Magda could read only if she stopped pretending to be modern.

By late afternoon, a municipal envelope with a two-headed stamp waited under the door asking to be let in. It was thick in the way of communications that intend to invoke a weight beyond their stock. Inside, a notice declared that, for the duration of one winter and for the radius defined by a table and a stove, her kitchen had been designated a venue of record for the oath’s amended domestic clause. There was a paragraph about fire exits that made sense even if you disapproved of exits on principle, a stipulation concerning the presence of beings whose legal status fluctuated with the phase of the moon, and a list of small compensations the city would pay without making her ask, which meant a man would arrive with a notebook and large ears and pay her less than she deserved while trying not to be ashamed of the arithmetic. There was also a line to sign where she would agree to accept the public when it came and to refuse it in a manner that did not produce riots in the stairwell.

“Prepare to have your Tuesdays eaten by disputes over tongs,” Petra said, reading over her shoulder and stretching her arms like a strongwoman considering whether to lift the refrigerator or persuade it to admit defeat. “They will bring tupperware with their grudges and ask the room to tell them where the leak is in their marriage. The city will adore it because it means fewer police reports in the evening and more satisfied small gods.”

“They will be hungry,” Magda said, and she wasn’t talking about soup. The letter made a neat folding sound when she tamed it back into its sleeve. “I will do what I can without allowing the towel to get ideas. And if the mildew comes because I forget and say pilgrim to a wall that loves rumors, you will come and scold the drawer until it dries in a decent frame of mind.”

The first supplicants came not on a Tuesday but on a Sabbath disguised as Wednesday. A pair of brothers holding between them a box of biscuits too sweet for honest adults asked to use the kitchen to settle whether the earth had a sense of humor about their father’s will. A woman with a baby asleep against her and cheeks that declared loudly that she never again intended to be asked to prove anything requested a space where she could tell a question to sit outside while she held her newborn up to be greeted by four corners and a drain who would forgive what it was asked to swallow later. A violinist with eyebrows like quotation marks asked if the stove would consider offering him an alibi for the night his bow had played a tune in a woman's window that did not belong to him. Magda took down names for her private book and not for the office’s book and scheduled the ones that smelled like sincerity before the ones that smelled like performance, and when the door closed after each life had entered and left, she washed the handles as if the city had breathed into her hands and required a gentle forgetting.

Evenings were different now because the air looked at her with work in mind. The crew returned to retrieve two cables they had sworn they had not left and to apologize to the cupboard for calling it stubborn when it had merely been conservative. The soundman with the shell ears brought a tin of shortbread as an offering, which Petra devoured with the fatalism of a woman resigned to falling in love with butter yet again, and the woman with the clipboard sat at the table after her shift and quietly wrote down, for her own peace, the number of times she had witnessed kindness without permission from a schedule. She said nothing aloud about any of it because she had learned that when you spoke about kindness in committees, men argued about definitions and invited hats to be passed.

The arithmetic pilgrim remained visible without being named, which is one of the city’s specialities. She went on the radio and talked about measures and sports and the mercy of being allowed to be obvious in a world that insists on cleverness. She gave interviews to newspapers nobody read on purpose and to one paper everyone bought because they liked the crossword, and in both she argued that making room for place to moderate was innovation disguised as sentimentality. She did not say Magda’s name. She called her “the respondent” once and then, with impeccable care, never again, as if the word had cut her lip. A rumor, oiled and sleek, glided across the internet that she was establishing a school for people who liked to answer quickly and to take audience and air into account equally, and this would be either a noble thing or a horror depending on whether she installed windows in the rooms.

On a night when the moon had not made up its mind about light, a young man knocked at the door and asked whether she accepted parcels from archives. He had the apologetic shoulders of someone sent by a superior who had not explained that apologies are sometimes worse than silence. He handed over a flat package wrapped in brown paper stamped with the municipal crest and the symbol of a fishhook bent into a question mark but not in wax this time, in ink so dark it looked like a bruise. Inside lay a folio of copies, nothing original you could breathe on and make change its mind, and within those copies a tracing of a page from a book Magda had seen once when she was young and had believed that dusty rooms would always be patient with her. The tracing showed the seal she already knew—hooked fish, question—but around it a ring of careful drawings of the letter D, repeated in as many hands as could be found in the archive in the year something had fallen down and hit a bureaucrat in the softest part of his heart.

There were notes in her teacher’s unsentimental hand that confirmed what the underworld of memos had suggested: the mark went back to an older association than television and a newer wickedness than empire. It belonged to a guild that had never declared itself fully because it preferred to be invited out like a ghost, and its various names all had to do with asking and collecting and the prying open of answers with grace and force alternately. The name that felt least like a pose and most like an admission was the Dowsers, which would have been ridiculous if not for the fact that in this city you could find underground water with a wire coat hanger and a headache if you knew how to listen. Below the ring of D’s, a phrase had been rubbed out and then rewritten, as if someone had regretted their ink and demanded second chances of the page. The phrase read: The question that yields to one who asks with hunger owes a debt to the place that has held it, and if the place refuses, the question must be worn like a stone around the neck until it softens.

She showed the folio to Petra because secrets fare better when stored in two bodies, particularly when one of those bodies belongs to a woman who can lift an unwieldy truth without creating a drama about her own biceps. They traced the notes with their eyes and made small maps of the city in the air above the table. They named corners where questions had drained away by themselves and corners where people loved to ask and rarely answered. They discussed whether the arithmetic pilgrim wore the ring with the fishhook as an advertisement or as a debt owed to hands she had shaken, and whether she had been taught to flick her eyes by people who preferred rooms with no soft furniture.

The cat interrupted by dragging a small object into the middle of the paper and dropping it with the complex pride of a creature who has brought you a thing that is not edible but important. It was a button made of smoke-coloured glass, the kind you find in old tins in old drawers in kitchens that have known both good and unkind women. In the button was embedded a hair, black and fine, and around the hole a faint scratch the exact shape of a letter the city refuses to pronounce when in a good mood. Magda picked it up and held it to the light and watched as the glass decided whether or not to be honest about what it had seen. “He has learned to collect witnesses,” Petra said, looking at the cat with affection and a smidgeon of terror because it is disorienting when your familiar begins to do the work of small archivists unasked.

The second invitation arrived in a fashion that introduced itself as polite and proved otherwise. There was no wax this time and no seal, only a note that had carried through so many rooms to reach her that it had become a traveller. It smelled of train stations and a cologne that wants to be a poem. The paper asked her presence at a gathering of the association hinted at in the tracing, in a hall whose address was given as the place where once men had sold three types of rope and an argument to go with each. It promised that if she came, she would be allowed to ask one question and to answer none. It warned, with a kind of courtliness that scratched at the skin, that if she refused, a question would be sent to her house anyway and would insist on being answered by the things there that could not claim professionalism.

Magda put the note down and picked up the folio again and then put both away because objects sometimes conspire if you leave them touching. She walked to the window and watched a bicycle decide bravely to be a vehicle even in snow that had ripened into slush. She was not in the habit of going into rooms that had a surplus of tweed and a deficit of sunlight. She understood that if she refused, the thing would not end but would come knocking like anything that wants to make you declare that you do or do not belong. She was able to admit to herself without drama that she had always been supple to invitations and extra resistant to summons.

Petra stood and stretched and rolled her shoulders as if warming up to carry somebody else’s mistake. “If you go,” she said, “I will walk you there without walking into the room. I will count the steps to the doorway and memorize them. I will plant coins in the street along the way for luck, which you will pretend to find casually. I will hang my coat on the nearest lion carved out of something complicated and ask it to watch for changes in your face when you come out.” She laid her large hands out on the table and pressed her palms to the wood that had officiated and decided that if anyone in that hall put their hand where it didn’t belong, the hall itself would have second thoughts. “If you do not go, there will be an envelope arrived at a terrible time and a bread you are baking will fall.”

The cat had opinions but had decided to package them in a shape that would not immediately make anyone leave the room. It jumped into Magda’s lap, turned itself into a loop of warm fur the exact geometry of eight, and purred off-key until the decision changed tone. The sound reached a place in Magda’s chest that made her think of being thirteen again and telling herself rules with salt and coins and the number of steps on a bridge. She knew that she would go because the way the letter was written had annoyed her into curiosity, and curiosity, when poked, repays the bother by carrying you into rooms where history keeps its old toothbrush in a glass by the sink.

The hall, when they reached it, was in disguise the way old buildings are when they wish to be polite to those who’ve come to scrape their money against a counter and go away with rope and disputation. The front had been painted the shade of neutrality that permits a shop to sell both paint thinner and advice, and only the door-knocker, an iron fish mid-sulk, betrayed the house’s appetite. Petra set coins in the cracks between stones with such casual artistry that three pigeons made approving noises. She counted the steps not to the door but to the nearest shadow big enough to hide a regret in. Magda knocked the way you knock when you are inviting yourself to confess.

Inside it smelled like dust that had chosen friends among books instead of floors, and like wine that had been opened in the afternoon by someone thinking about the pace of their own heartbeat. The room had three long tables and many chairs and a clerk with a chin like a plinth. The association had assembled themselves in the clothes they wear when they know they may be asked to stand and be admired while pretending not to mind the draft. Rings gleamed in good taste and in lack of it. A woman with a scar along her eyebrow the shape of a scythe leaned against a radiator with the warmth of a person who arranges temperatures for a living. A man in a sweater with elbow patches the exact tone of his skepticism unfolded his arms and refolded them in a way that gave the impression of generosity without requiring him to offer it.

They greeted her by not greeting her, which is the manner of groups that prefer to watch you take your first steps on their floor and judge whether or not you are likely to embarrass their rug. She decided to be rude in a way that is perceived, in certain circles, as elegance. She nodded to the clerk as if they shared a private misgiving about the invoices, touched the radiator as if introducing the bones in her hands to its iron, and then looked neither left nor right but at the ceiling, because ceilings in such rooms hold more honest opinions than the painting does. The ceiling was cracked the way skin cracks in winter and then pretends it is fine in spring, and it had patched itself with careful attention, which meant someone here was capable of maintenance without fanfare.

The arithmetic pilgrim was absent and present both. Her name was not said and not permitted, and somehow every absence in the room arranged itself as if keeping a chair free for a person who had already decided whether to sit. The clerk gave Magda a token shaped like a drop of water and told her she could ask one question of place and not of person and that if she asked the wrong one the place would call it wrong by arranging everyone’s coughs into a verdict. He added, with an amusement that fit his chin, that if she attempted to leave without partaking of their bread and their overly earnest cheese, the door would seize up and require a mechanic with intentions.

She considered the room and where it had learned to stand, considered the floorboards and the years that had taught them to remain unbroken when men in boots or women in newly-heel-bearing shoes marched in with law extending just behind them like a pale. She had half a mind to ask the table what had been signed on it that should not have been, and the other half to ask the radiator what it had overheard about water and fire. Instead she breathed and did what she had taught herself to do in kitchens and cabins: she asked the room what question would make it feel that it had been treated like a person and not a stage.

“What would you like me to ask,” she said softly, letting the words use the parts of her mouth that most like soup. “And what are you tired of hearing. And what, if answered, would make you permit this association to claim that they have a right, however temporary, to whisper?” The clerk smiled not displeased. The elbow-patched man arranged his face to conceal his intimacy with the concept of relief. The woman by the radiator watched her fingers as if admiring the uncomplaining competence of tendons. The room answered in the airy voice of plaster and like all old houses it added a complaint because complaining is a right earned by seeing too much.

“Ask if they are willing to pay in silence,” it said, and its words, though not lawyerly, had the careful structure of someone who has been talked over and has decided to pull out a different chair. “Ask whether they will give you a season in which they do not ask and only allow the city to ask them to be kind. Ask them whether they will leave one corner empty in all their rooms where a person who does not like questions can hide and not be smoked out. Ask whether they are as good at receiving as they are at prying.” The ceiling cracked its knuckles in satisfaction as if it had finally been invited to its own party. The radiator approved by not hissing, which is as loud as radiators get when expressing contentment.

Magda turned to the assembled and asked the room’s question because intermediaries have their obligations too. The association, caught unready by being asked to consider and not to promise cunning things, looked at one another and, like all organisms that wish to survive, made a plan so fast that plan looked like character. The clerk cleared his throat and did not perform: he said that yes, they would say nothing for a season and see if a different skill, one less applauded, did in fact exist in them. The man with elbow patches looked pained and agreed with his eyebrows. The woman by the radiator nodded, the nod of someone conjugating a verb she had been avoiding. Someone in the back whispered that the mildew penalty for naming had been effective and perhaps should be expanded to include insulting particular benches, and the room downstairs, which had a bench with pride but not vanity, twitched its leg in warning.

They offered her the bread and the cheese as threatened. She ate both politely. They poured her wine that had wanted to be better but had learned pragmatism and that grape’s particular humility. The clerk gave her a paper like a recipe that set down the season of silence and the empty corner rule and an address to which she could send any small gods found in jars on Thursdays. Then, because she had accepted their bread, she did as courtesy demanded and asked them for a single thing in return that would not reveal hunger but would remind their bodies later that their mouths had been honest. She asked for the map of those who kept the ring with the fishhook close, not their names or their domiciles, because names and addresses are for police and letter carriers, but the pattern of what places they preferred, what weather they coveted, and at what hour they liked to commit their questions to paper. The clerk, who liked accurate maps more than most, glanced at the ceiling, which cracked once in approval, and said yes.

Outside, Petra exhaled the temperature of the visitor’s hall and pushed a coin with her boot into a crack that had not been there when they arrived. “You were long but not too long,” she said, which amounted to a public laurel in her register. “The lion says five men pretended not to know how to lean, and two women pretended not to notice them pretending. There is a man in the third-story window across the street who is very good at reading backward and has been reading a book that was not written in that order. I told him to mind his business with my eyebrows.”

They walked toward the canal because the canal thinks better of people who use it to wash thoughts rather than to shove them from one bank to another. Snow had given up its career ambitions for the week and fallen back into being weather; it gathered respectfully along the railings and avoided accusing pedestrians of insufficient romance. On the bridge, a boy threw a handful of something into the air and watched as it became not enough confetti and too much dust. He looked at Magda with the specific gravity assigned to adults who sometimes know the secret rules and said that he had seen her on a thing and then had watched a kettle and discovered that kettles were not merely appliances but instruments. She thanked him in a language that does not make boys feel managed, and he nodded, satisfied to have been recognized by a correct vowel.

Her kitchen looked at her when she returned the way kitchens do when you bring in too many stories: it assessed the load-bearing capacity of the table and suggested a stew. Petra hung her coat and announced that she would nap for forty minutes like a soldier and be woken with cruelty in case the city wanted to run again. The cat, having successfully pilfered another button from somewhere no one would admit to, hid it behind the sugar, which pretended not to notice even while cataloguing the weight and the scratch. A small flyer had come under the door advertising a new thing: a man at the market was selling black sweets molded in the shape of a question mark fish, dusted with sugar so they looked like they had been dredged through a conversation. The price was affordable, which meant there was a plan to make back the loss on something else, and Magda smiled because the city had already begun metabolizing the spectacle into treats and trinkets. That was better than it being turned into doctrine, which makes bad bread and worse neighbors.

Night came and brought with it neither dread nor rest, something in-between that Magda had learned to inventory without impatience. She turned the clocks to face out again because she had guests coming tomorrow and guests feel untrusted when time is told to avert its gaze. She wrote two invoices and threw them away because she had used too much righteousness in the phrasing; then she wrote them again in the voice of a person who knows that payment is not the same as gratitude and that insisting otherwise ruins soup. She set aside a place on a shelf for the jar the technicians would bring if they found spirits inside her outlets, and she spoke aloud to the outlets because electrical entities prefer to be addressed before they are inspected. She told them that if they had sheltered any stray whispers out of pity for a threadbare argument, now was the time to send them into the stairwell to choose different doors.

She slept at last, not the sleep of the unbothered but one of those municipal rests you get when a city has promised you that, for a few hours, it will keep your name out of papers and your streetlamp lit. In her dream she took the tram to the end of the line and discovered that the last stop was an enormous pot placed on a square in which onions browned to applause. She woke to the cat kneading her shoulder with intent that was affectionate and legislative, and to the sound of a trolley somewhere being asked to apologize by a track. She brewed coffee because tea is for mending, and this morning was for soldering. She set out cups because people would come and ask her to be precise without being sharp, and she could do that for the length of this winter and the width of this table and not longer.

The bell rang once and did not ring a second time. No one stood in the doorway when she opened it, which did not make her suspicious because absence is this city’s most practiced trick. On the mat lay a small box wrapped in paper democratic enough to have contained meat or poetry. She brought it inside, checked it for municipal rats and divine sarcasm, found none, and unwrapped it with the care you give a gift from someone who does not know yet whether to apologize. Inside lay flour packed around an object wrapped again in cloth. She pulled back the cloth and found a loaf shaped like a question mark, proofed and baked with skill somewhere between old village hands and new city nerve. Under it there was a card with no name and three words written in a script she recognized at once because she had seen it move through lights like a snake learning to speak. The three words read: Next: your bridge.

She stared at the bread until its heat made the paper humble. She felt the hinge in her jaw where unkindness likes to hide click into place and then relax because she would not allow it space this morning. Bridge was not only a place in Vienna with a view and history; it was a thing you build to join shores that pretend to want distance. It was also a term in certain rooms for the interim between scenes when you allow the audience to breathe and then decide whether to clap or leave. She understood at once twelve meanings and knew there were thirty more. She understood that there would be a move to take the proceedings out of kitchens and out of wheels and onto the skin of the city’s most public arches, where wind has opinions and pigeons possess rights. She understood that she would have to say yes if the invitation invoked something older than her refusal and that she would have to bring Petra because bridges, like kitchens, do not tolerate loneliness well.

She sliced the bread and smelled a joke braided into its crumb. It had been baked by someone who knew sugar is impolite in rye unless it is made to apologize with salt. She ate a piece and decided to keep the rest in case a bridge had a taste for symbolism later and could be bribed. She put the card with the three words on the high shelf because things above your line of sight have less power over your day than things below it. The cat jumped up and batted the card once and then let it be because even cats know that some games are better played with witnesses.

Petra came in then, hair in a braid that had slept and woken more dignified than most people do.
