She saw the bread, read the three words, and made a face that in her dialect meant both we expected this and I was hoping for a different act. “Good,” she said, pouring coffee into cups that had long ago agreed to be identically chipped. “Let her take the air and see if it will side with anyone who talks to it like a pet. I will bring rope and I will not tell you why until I need to.” She sat and dunked her bread with the seriousness of a theologian practicing mischief. “You will wear a hat because bridges are vain and like it when their visitors dress for the occasion. And you will ask the city, at the top, to please between now and then avoid breaking any old men's hips, because bridges like to make their points in ways that make new widows, and I am tired of that drama.”

Magda nodded and felt the city turn its head toward them because it enjoys being asked to play fair when everyone expects it to be only romantic and cruel. She wrote a note to the office that watched the oath with two sentences that said six things; she sent Petra out to buy mustard because soup without mustard would make the day less honest; she ran a hand along the towel and thanked it for its lineage and asked it to tolerate more elbows. She did not say arithmetic or pilgrim or any proper names at all. She said bridge out loud because saying it taught her mouth how the air would feel when she stood where the invitation wanted her to stand. She believed, because belief is a traitor and a servant both, that place would not refuse her if she arrived hungry and wearing a hat that made a bridge feel taller. She put the bread on a plate because even jokes deserve to be served and not eaten from paper when they are trying to be metaphors, and she waited for the city to drop its next hint in the bowl by the door where coins and keys sleep between errands.

Chapter 10

The day the bridge took up residence in her mouth began with sensible shoes and a superstition she thought she’d retired. She dressed for the air as if it were a particular aunt—affectionate, prone to comment, tender to hats—and she set out with Petra to walk the city’s spans the way you visit elders before making a decision that will obligate your knees. A notice from the office had been hand-delivered at dawn by a boy in municipal blue who had the look of a person dignified by errands; it stipulated that the officiant must be of sound footing, that the river be in a mood to listen, that railings be briefed against grandstanding, and that the amended clause about feeding witnesses be observed with sincerity and spoons that did not snap under moral weight. A stamp on the notice bore two arches with a small fishhook between them, which meant either someone had a sense of humor at City Hall or the association had discovered self-awareness and was trying it on.

They started with the small bridges over the canal because practice is kinder on modest architecture. Schwedenbrücke hunkered in its coat of traffic and steel like a person willing to be touched but not hugged; it tolerated questions the way bank clerks tolerate the lunch hour. Augartenbrücke was easier; it breathed and remembered lovers who had made of its midspan a private pronoun and children who had dropped marbles into the water to see whether the river spoke the language of games. Friedensbrücke, when they reached it, looked at Magda the way old friends look at you when they are practicing not saying I told you so. It had known her feet once when she had believed that counting could keep death polite, and it did not hold the belief against her. It had a broad back and a practical soul, which is an underrated quality in officiants.

“Yours,” Petra said, not because the bridge had put out a mat with her name on it but because the air took that particular texture people acquire when they have made room for a person to be braver than yesterday. There were stains on the girders shaped like the handprints of weather; there were pigeons in their correct number, neither too many to invite contempt nor too few to worry priests. The water below behaved; it had been sullen lately, winter having made it heavy, but today it had the resigned efficiency of a waiter in a café where the coffee is never sent back. Magda set her palm against the parapet and felt the same small slow thrum she remembered from when she was thirteen and her bones were new to a city that believed in its own spine.

The office brought its devices and courtesies at noon. The inspector with the spoon, now a minor celebrity in his own circles, set a bowl against the wind and forced it to respect the old experiment; the spoon did not even twitch when the first dumb question was asked over the canal by a clerk practicing for television, which made two men in hi-vis jackets beam like uncles. A woman with a coil of bright rope and a notebook came to measure everything that might be measured and marked out a rectangle of witness on the east side where the light would not insult cameras into making art. She listened gravely when Petra asked for anchor points and then watched with professional interest as Petra looped her rope around a lamppost and a parapet as if she were teaching the bridge a knot that a boat would approve of without becoming sentimental. A placard went up at the north approach, drawing its authority from the kind of font that assures you doctors are involved: Oath of Contest, Domestic Amendment in Effect, Officiant: Friedensbrücke, Witnesses Must Be Available for Soup.

Word had spread without anyone having to push it. In Vienna rumors commute for free and often arrive before you do with your bag. By midafternoon women with strong handbags and men with ordinary minds and clever children had begun to pause, calculate the probable time of the spectacle, and make shopping lists accordingly. Bruno, clutching an offensively small notebook and wearing a respectably subdued hat, tried to insinuate himself into the crew by claiming his great-uncle had once oiled a bolt on the same span, then thought better of it when Petra folded her arms and let her hands communicate, without recourse to verbs, the shape of the fee for men with notebooks. The clipboard woman appeared like a grant come in under budget, hair braided with duty, and reviewed the tape marked along the pavement as if it were a new policy on rights-of-way and not a gesture of prudence towards a bridge with a sense of its own dignity.

The arithmetic pilgrim sent no envelope this time because addresses had become superfluous; still, just before four, a car that enjoyed thinking of itself as a carriage arrived, and she disembarked with the economy of a person who knows that stairs pay attention. Her coat had learned the art of not being an event; it worried the edges of its own elegance but did not apologize, and her thumb ring made its narrow address on her hand like a commentary you cannot disagree with without looking petty. She took in the rope, the soup cauldrons—two, braced on gas rings lugged up from the kitchen by a crew who had decided to enjoy being useful today—the bowl and spoon, the municipal faces, the river. She smiled into the air with the minimum of teeth necessary to say: I see you seeing me; give me a second to make you comfortable with that fact.

“I have brought no wire,” she said, pitching the line to carry to the places that matter—the operator standing half-disguised behind a kiosk, the clipboard, the inspector, the bridge—and three pigeons made skeptical noises in unison because pigeons believe in evidence, not promises. Her crew followed behind with less arrogance than last night, subdued by something that had not been part of any training-day module: the knowledge of being permitted on sufferance by a thing with rivets. The camera lowered its head like a penitent altar boy and blinked at the water with an expression that could be read as humility if you had learned how to ascribe virtue to machines.

“Hat,” Petra said softly, and Magda, who had chosen hers at noon with the seriousness of someone choosing a tone, put it on. It was sensible but not hostile to compliments, with a small ribbon whose behavior could be described as moral. The wind considered it on her and agreed not to make trouble unless she was rude. She adjusted the brim, set the ladle where it could do its duty with some flourish, and stepped to the chalk line that had been laid down between two patches of salt as if the city were making a recipe it refused to write down.

When the hour came, it did not announce itself with bells so much as with a tightening in the air common to theatres and courts and kitchens where apologies are about to be offered. People arranged their faces into expressions they believed would be flattering in the memories of others; children corrected them. The inspector tested the silence a final time and nodded to the bridge the way you nod to someone you have agreed to call by their first name for the duration of a project. The bridge hummed once, a sound you could feel in your ankles more than your ears, and the camera flinched, which endeared it to three electricians and one saint.

“Declare span,” the bridge said, speaking through its iron and concrete, every stress line suddenly a throat. The voice had that quality old metal has in winter—warmed by the friction of weather, slowed by thought. “Declare footings. Declare weight allowable without damage to dignity.” The officiant had no time for nonsense, but its tolerance for ordinary human attempts made of those present an assembly of the correct size. Magda was grateful all at once for having learned to be polite to stairs as a child; bridges, like stairs, can be asked to be kind if you remember they are not there for you.

“North to south,” she said, “with room for waste and the trumpet of impatience. Footings in the facts men poured in good moods and bad. Weight to include velvet and the way people pretend not to look when lovers fight.” She let the grammar wear its boots. The arithmetic pilgrim, without attempting to improve on it, added her declaratives as if offering the officiant a bouquet without the embarrassment of flowers. “From the city that calls itself first to the one that acts like it,” she said, naming the districts in the old way that counts bridges as a kind of jewelry. “Footings in losses we agreed to forget. Weight to include ratings, friction, and the privilege of having come farther than anyone expected.”

The bridge accepted both, as though its ledger had a column labeled generosity. The camera’s light moved from green to a meek red, and the inspector’s spoon stayed polite. The river decided not to show off with a floating branch performing dramatics. The voice that had held the quiz show together arrived late, as if having run from an appointment, and tried to sound as if it had always lived in girders; it did a respectable job for something that had been designed to sell adverts between competition and haircut. “Contest resumes,” it said, reading off a sheet that had been dampened by the weather and hardened by policy. “Officiant: Friedensbrücke. Scope public and elevated. Wire denied. Audience disarmed of sharp derision and permitted warm commentary. Witnesses to be fed first. Petitioners to speak as issued.”

Magda knew the bridge would not want theatrics dressed as questions. This was a place that preferred practical confessions to prettified lies, surefooted nouns to the kind of adjectives that make boys write songs. She felt the thrum under her hand with the exactness of a metronome that has been influenced by love. The first question rose not from the ceiling of a cabin this time but from the river itself, which is the city’s memory cooled into a habit. “What did counting do,” it asked, and the water slapped the pier in a rhythm that was almost kind to memory. “When you put numbers between yourself and sorrow, what did you build. Did the bridge help.”

“It made time put its foot precisely and refrain from running,” she said, and the answer was neither elegant nor hungry, which pleased the air. “It gave me something to tell my bones to do that wasn’t thinking about lemon and the thing the disinfectant couldn’t cover. It did not help my mother stay; it helped me not to drop. The bridge offered me an honest surface and the dignity of a tangent. It tolerated my small arithmetic without adjusting its own and I am grateful to it, which is not the same as saying I was right.”

The arithmetic pilgrim listened in a manner more interesting than her practiced attentiveness; she did not tap her ring, and her eyes did not travel left for forbidden aid. The wind put a flat palm on her mouth as if to test whether it would be a friend to her voice. “Counting makes a promise to your pride,” she said, speaking to the river and to every city that had trained itself to pretend it can be measured without flattery. “It says you will not be caught unawares by the same drop twice. It’s theatre you do for yourself that sometimes keeps you from looking down. I did not count. I learned to skip, and I lost things. I lost things and told myself the loss was speed.”

The bridge liked the honesty of it in a way that admits bias; spans are constructed by people who trust numbers enough to risk poetry. The second question came in the voice of iron: “Define toll, in a century that has learned to pay without putting coins on a table.” It was an ancient word bristling with modern teeth. The ring of witnesses sharpened their faces, and Petra, who could have answered in three dialects and a curse, rested her weight on both feet as if preparing to carry whatever came next.

“A toll is the price of not drowning,” Magda said, because she had left fancy in the kitchen on purpose. “It’s the bit you owe the thing that bears you, even if you pretend it owes you. It can be money, or it can be the promise to leave something on the far side that you picked up on the near, because not everything loves being carried. It is also a story you tell the ones behind you about the wind up here, so they come ready. In courts it is called court fees. In kitchens it is called washing up.” She let herself smile, and three men nearby felt themselves become less ridiculous for having brought thermoses.

“The toll is audience,” the pilgrim said, and because she had chosen that as her instrument she paid in her own coin without apology. “I cross because people hope to see me cross, and their hope makes the span less long. The price is I must go back and forth more times than I would if no one watched. The price is to be always observed and thus never unmade.” She said it like a ledger entry, and the bridge, which had ledger in its bones and remembered every footstep like a numerator, allowed itself to be persuaded that audience could be a legitimate currency if not the only clean one.

The third question, as old as bridges and as new as paperless tickets, came from the underside, from the steel that only birds and vagrants look at. “What will you refuse to carry across,” it asked, and a train in the distance added its long opinion to the air. Magda thought of what she had seen dragged from bank to bank by people who believed distance fixed virtue. She thought of gossip disguised as mercy and mercy disguised as pity and pity disguised as a knife.

“Cruelty that is proud of itself,” she said. “Weapons that have been disguised as etiquette. Promises that have been hollowed by practice. I will not carry proofs of other people’s disappointments across as if they were trophies, and I will not carry my own righteousness when it is bigger than my hunger. I will carry sadness because it does not know better, and I will carry boredom because sometimes it is a virtue. I will not carry a wire, even if asked, even if told it is the modern way to cross.”

“Regret performed for effect,” the pilgrim said, and you could tell she had had to teach herself the difference between regret and rehearsal. “Self-pity in good clothes. Lies that improve ratings and break floors. The particular kind of contempt that is taught in certain rooms where men practice winning without eating afterward with the people they beat.” She had chosen her refusals with care, and the crowd, which had learned this winter the taste of admission, found themselves willing to be moved by someone who had also been briefly willing to be small.

A motion by the parapet, small enough to be plausibly accidental, made Petra’s rope hand twitch. A young man with a device the color of indifference had been inviting a whisper to climb his sleeve; it hummed with that dry signature Magda had learned to hear in rooms that pretend to be silent. Before the inspector could be offended or the clipboard can pronounce the word violation with relish, the wind took a sudden interest in a flap of paper attached to the device. Petra did not make a scene, because scenes give wire confidence; she stepped as if retrieving a chestnut from an unwise pigeon and lifted the rope in a way that moved the young man and his hum and their hopes two meters south into a region where the city’s superstition about unlucky numbers held jurisdiction. The hum met a cross-current, panicked, and slipped into the river with a small spark that the water politely ignored. The inspector marked something on a form with a line that suggested gratitude, and Magda sent some of hers down the rope into Petra’s palm.

It was the bridge’s turn to ask a local question, something in the way of house rules. “Foot traffic has a right-of-way when weather and fear conspire to make running likely,” it said, quoting its own private ordinance compiled from a hundred years of breath. “Under the amended clause, witnesses must be fed. Who feeds the bridge.” It was not an accusation; it was a practical inquiry from a host who had learned belatedly to enjoy being thanked.

“We feed you with names you are allowed to keep,” Magda said. “With palms that carry warmth across. With the small humor of hats. With steps that touch and do not strike. With soup steam, if you consent. With the habit of saying thank you to the railings in winter without telling anyone we did it.” She glanced at the cauldrons, where Petra and a girl from a bakery who had appointed herself spoon-handle-guardian were managing the delicacies of hot things near politics. They had chosen a soup with good intentions and better salt, and it was the kind of broth that makes witnesses respectable even when their opinions lean untidy.

“With attention,” the pilgrim said, and this time she kept it modest. “Bridge-feeding is attendance without appropriation. It is taking a photograph and not showing it to anyone. It is telling small boys to stop carving obscenities in the paint because there are better walls for that, and then writing the obscenity yourself in a place that knows how to forgive.” There was laughter, not cruel, and the river made a noise like the part of applause that is for yourself.

The officiant liked it, and because it liked it, the fourth question allowed itself to be the kind that leaves a mark without obvious handwriting. “Which shore do you live on,” it asked both of them without making a joke of metaphor, “and what tax do you pay to go home.” It was always a dirty secret of bridges that they favor one bank; the honest ones admit it, the splendid ones deny it, the useful ones shrug and do their work. Magda looked downriver to where the canal pretended it was river and then to the buildings behind her with their domestic faces and their windows that had learned her name without asking permission.

“Whichever shore has the kitchen I’ve promised to return to,” she said, and she felt the word kitchen do its new work in the air like a saint promoted reluctantly. “If I am honest, it is not the bank with more lights. It is the one where the ground knows the grammar of my step. The tax is that I must come back the long way sometimes when I have said something too sharp, and the bridge charges me in humility. I pay it because it keeps the wood in my apartment from drying out.”

“I live on the shore with the crowd,” the pilgrim said, and there was no self-loathing in it, only the cool clarity of a person who has learned what she is permitted to love. “I pay by sleeping badly, by losing the names of dogs, by forgetting to bring change, by keeping my hands gentle longer than I would if no one watched.” That last admission hung there between them like a piece of fruit neither wanted to claim and neither would drop, and the bridge, which has little patience for coyness, cleared its iron throat and threw them a reprieve in the form of a procedural.

The voice of the office, damp and chastened, reminded them that under the arc clause each party could ask one question of the water without it counting against the other’s breath. Magda asked first because generosity is craft as well as courtesy and some crafts require precedence to matter. “What have you refused,” she said to the river, remembering an August years ago when it had turned its back on three boys pushing a supermarket trolley out toward the middle. “What have you insisted on carrying to the sea even when the city begged you to give it back.”

“Names,” the water said, and the wind folded in respectfully because even air can be taught to behave when grief begins to inflate. “I refuse to keep names that have been shouted at me; I carry them away no matter how much stone holds on. I keep the names breathed instead. Those I keep long enough for the fish to learn and the mud to memorize. I declined a bicycle that believed it was a crown. I returned a crown that wanted to be a bicycle. I have kept three songs because no one had the courage to sing them aloud on land, and a city must have a secret or it turns to glass.”

The pilgrim asked the water a question that was both clever and true, which is a dangerous combination when the officiant is a structure with a conscience. “How do you measure audience,” she asked, and the musicians gathered under the western arch who had hoped for a moment did grin at the precision of it. “Not in counts,” she added, as if to reassure Magda that she understood the rules of this place and that her old instruments had learned to tune themselves for nights like this. “But in weather.”

“By the sway of birds and the way cigarette smoke hangs or hurries,” the water said. “By whether children hush each other or no one can tolerate hush. By how long the bread thrown to ducks admits its error and dissolves into humility. By the weight of winter coats on railings and the conversations they remember. By whether the bridge feels heavier when you leave than when you came.” The bridge hummed assent, because it is a joy to be translated into a form the city can comprehend without swallowing, and the inspector made one last flourish with his pen because he was remembering how to distrust the wire without embarrassment.

The ritual piece—names of productions, numbering of minutes, reminding of penalties—came next because even amended ceremonies must maintain a minimal decency. The clipboard read from her pristine, new-shortened form that neither party had said the other’s name out loud, which meant everyone’s chairs would be safe from mildew so long as no one got clever in an after-dinner speech. The office praised the rope for its cooperation and asked gently that it might be allowed to retire before someone built a story around it. Petra complied with a flourish that made three teenagers decide to learn knots for reasons other than romance, and the rope coiled itself with the kind of elegance that suggests all good tools know when they have been precisely used.

“Instrument,” said the bridge, not so much out of a need to hear a confession as out of the pedagogical desire to see if a lesson had stuck. The audience made a little sound because repetition feels like belonging, and the soup chose that moment to reach a perfect simmer, a domestic amen that made the whole span smell briefly like a decision you are proud of. The pilgrim raised her hand in a motion that looked like surrender and was not. “Audience, as declared,” she said, and the bridge refused to sneer at it because it had seen armies and parades and lovers; it knew that sometimes being watched keeps you from falling. Magda laid her palm on the stone and said “place” again with the extra gravity that comes when you are repeating something to make it true rather than interesting, and both the stone and the sound conceded the legitimacy of her choice.

There was one more thing the officiant required, because bridges do not like to be left in the state of anticipation that roads prefer. “Admit danger,” it said, and horses stamped somewhere not present because they heard their word called. “Not to each other. To the city.” This was the question that divides pageants from rites. The men with thermoses sipped as if coffee could be a moral position, and the children stilled with an attention that had nothing to do with parents’ hands on collars.

“If we keep doing this wrong,” Magda said, and she felt the hat approve of her posture, “we will teach the city to clap at the wrong time. We will teach it to prefer cleverness to repair, theatre to stairs. We will break the habit of ordinary chairs being enough. We will invite pretty laws to dine with brutal ones and the polite knives will learn the names of throats. If we do it right, we might build a grammar for rooms that have been waiting centuries to be allowed to speak without being called sentimental. The danger is becoming good at the wrong magic.”

“If we keep doing this wrong,” the pilgrim said in a voice for once plain as unmagicked bread, “I will become so adept at being watched that I will forget how to stop. The city will forget how to be interesting when no one is filming it. We will build a market for a thing that ought to be a sacrament, and the market will eat it as markets do. The danger is we make a bridge out of knives again and then have the nerve to complain about blood.” She looked at Magda when she said it with a species of warmth that resembled respect and might just have been professional greed, which is a cousin of it.

The verdict, when it came, did not do the thing verdicts usually do. It did not assign a winner that could be tallied, monetized, sold later in sugar, or tattooed on a forum’s masthead. It took the shape of instructions with teeth, and the teeth were small enough to get between the fibers of everyday life, which is where policy lives if it intends to survive. “Contest is complete,” said the bridge, and the north wind run its fingers through pigeon feathers with approval. “Petitioner releases one edge of the compass to place when place insists. Respondent declares publicly that fair and kind are different but compatible and will not be used as each other’s alibis. Both will feed witnesses at future spectacles and not let hunger be an aesthetic. Wires will be treated as guests and made to wait outside with the coats. City will reserve the right to refuse fun if it endangers chairs. Names remain unsaid in public for the length of a winter and the angle of this hat.”

A ripple went through the crowd that felt like gratitude calming a muscle. The inspector wrote “complete” in a box that had waited patient months to be filled and then underlined it because men who marry spoons become romantic about outcomes in the correct way. The clipboard woman allowed herself the rare pleasure of closing a file before her breath ended, which in her trade is usually a luxury reserved for deaths and elections. Petra ladled soup with the righteous exhaustion of a priest after a successful holiday, and when someone tried to clap too early she inclined her head at them with such precise disappointment that the clap resolved itself into a better-timed embrace of the air.

They ate. The pilgrim burned her tongue a little, which she bore with the composure of someone who has learned not to show the city her blister. The operator from the wheel accepted a bowl and stood where he could see both banks, which is the position men who do good work choose without advertisement. A boy fed bread to ducks and then apologized under his breath for the sugar in it, which is a scandal in water circles, and a duck forgave him by biting his bootlace instead of his finger. The river inhaled the warmth and kept its private count. A woman on crutches stayed for the whole thing and did not resent the cold because the bridge had remembered to dip, at the right moment, and make everyone feel tall.

“You were not fair,” Petra murmured to Magda later, when the span had resumed its ordinary job of letting people cheat at geography. “And you were kind enough that children will be allowed to borrow your name when they argue with stairs. She was not kind, but she was fair enough that the city forgave her ring and will stop taking milk from her in cafés twice on nine days out of ten. The bridge was itself, which is the real miracle.”

“I will write the office and thank them for remembering to be ashamed of wires,” Magda said, and she felt the tide of dread that had been riding in her ribcage since the bread in the shape of a question had arrived recede to a level where you can walk without lifting your knees too high. “And then I will go home and unteach the towels what applause sounds like. They got ideas last night and kept their edges out to be admired.”

The arithmetic pilgrim approached with that clean step she had perfected for camera and court alike, and held out her hand the way you offer someone a lighter in the wind. They did not shake because sometimes that is a superstition and sometimes it is hygiene and sometimes it is mercy; they let their hands talk near each other like diplomats. “Next,” she said, and she said it without sugar and without injury. “Not because of ratings. Because bridges are addictive and I would like to see what a street with a market knows. I will not bring wire. I will bring somebody who has never answered a question into a microphone and see if it improves or ruins them.”

“Next,” Magda agreed, and she did not pretend the word lacked gravity. “Because the city likes to hear itself in different rooms. Because a market has a grammar that has taught more people manners than any school. Because I have a debt to a baker who told my fortune once with crumbs.” They stood there very briefly in a place where compromises were honest, and then the pilgrim turned away with the unkind grace of someone who has taught motion to keep her from growing a conscience, and Magda turned homeward with Petra at her side, which is how courage has survived the winter so far.

The cat met them three streets from the bridge with a disdainful efficiency that suggested it had been out all afternoon filing reports with the small gods. It had acquired a ticket stub that said in a dead language: for standing where the air is thinner and not pretending to be taller, and it dropped it at Petra’s feet as if to implicate her in elegance. At home, the kitchen performed its trick of smelling like soup even after the spoons had been washed, which is a little-known miracle separate from onions entirely. The towel, well pleased with its new clerical status, had been left a note by the inspector written with the municipal courtesy of a person who prefers to compliment cloth in private: Thank you for officiating in absentia. It had a stamp with two arches and a fishhook and an apology for the starch.

Letters multiplied like a kind of respectable fungus on the mat by morning. One was from the association with a map made in good faith showing where those who wore the fishhook ring liked to stand, and at what hours their questions bit. The pattern was less elegant than prophecy and more practical than menace; it had clusters around courtyards and tram stops, and three dots along the market street Petra had mentioned which suggested the next place would be loud in a human way. Another letter came with the city stamp upside down, which could be read as whimsy or haste; it contained a gentle request that Magda consider making a list of chairs that had suffered under the amended clause’s attention, to be repaired at public expense because people had begun to carry their sorrow into kitchens, and sorrow sits too heavily for cheap wood.

She made tea because coffee had acquired too many approvals in the last twenty-four hours and deserved a rest. Petra sprawled in the chair the cat had been saving for her and announced that she would steal for the market event three aprons from the theatre museum under a pretense that made art exact its tithe from politics. Magda counted spoons and discovered, with a privately pleased little gasp, that one had learned restraint; if shaken it did not try to answer. She considered the bridge, which had taken their talk and converted it to policy the way stomachs turn soup into blood. She considered the pilgrim, who had discovered late a habit of not cheating and might find it to her taste. She considered the city, which had begun to enjoy being addressed at last in sentences with verbs that did not threaten to take your coat.

At noon, the boy from the office with the honorable shoulders returned with a brand-new form—Market Clause, addendum to the domestic and elevated provisions—and a wad of blue tape. It said that stalls are officiants if asked in chorus, that haggling counts as precedent but not law, that card tables have no jurisdiction unless they have been blessed by fruit, and that under no circumstances may a chicken be cross-examined without consent. The penalty for premature clapping would be revised to include the sudden proliferation of coriander in unsuitable dishes. The boy read this aloud with straight face and handed over the tape with grave palms, and Petra, not able to help herself, saluted the tape as if it had just been promoted.

That night, because endings are for festivals and this winter had decided on continuations, Magda sat at the table with the folio of tracings of old D’s and wrote in the margins where her teacher’s neat hand had once refused academies their comfort. She recorded that the bridge had insisted on tolls in soup and mercy instead of coin and swagger, and that the air had behaved. She wrote that the city had enjoyed itself without destroying furniture, and that sometimes this is what religion looks like for people who no longer like altars but still need things that require washing up. She put down that audience can be an instrument if tuned by shame and that place, when given a job, does it honestly and resentful only if you forget to let it nap.

The cat, apostolic in its certainty that nothing serious happens that does not eventually impinge upon bowls, took up residence on the shelf where the new jars for spirits would sit, as if to bless in advance the future hauntings. Petra fell asleep on the couch with a roll of tape in her fist and the rope coiled by the door as if it had decided to become a pet. The market would make a noise tomorrow and pretend to be a thunderstorm, and someone would ask a question that made a chest of lemons confess to immortality. A bridge had stamped a decision on the day. A kitchen had rewritten one line of law by browning onions with discipline. The wheel, across town, spun once in the late wind and made a sound like a man remembering to apologize to a woman who had been right. And the city, turning under its winter hat, tried out a new habit in the mirror: listening, not for clapping or for footfall, but for the small syllables of places clearing their throats.
